fields.body:
Summary

What a year. I started the year off leaving everything behind with the intention of long-term travel. I am ending the year being confused as hell as to what I’m going to be doing in the future, but with many ideas in mind. One thing that I’ve learned is that with flexibility comes uncertainty. My plans have slowly turned into ideas, and they change almost daily.

I started the year off with the intention of finding a way to live a sustainable life while traveling. Having a travel blog and various options that arise when obtaining a large audience was what I first attempted. Within a few months I realized better opportunities awaited me, and this blog became a personal hobby, dropping from my priority list.

I began getting heavier into web development while living in Medellin Colombia, and launched my second project Travel Blog Source. Above everything else, I love doing web development. I did it for free for many months, just because I enjoy it. It was a great idea, and I still believe with the right dedication the idea would work. However, when it came time to do the marketing, I lost interest.

After 4 months in Colombia, it was time to leave. I headed south, even though my heart was not all the way in it. My time in Ecuador was not the best month of my life, and I quickly re-learned the ups and downs of traveling. Luckily enough, I was not tied to anything, and I moved onto Peru after spending a month in the mountain regions of Ecuador.

My stay in Peru was more extended that I had planned. This is when I learned that my travel plans are never concrete. I picked up a client for web development within the first weeks in Peru, and it was a project that interested me, a lot. I spent about a month in Peru doing some touristy-ish stuff in northern Peru, but by the time I got into Lima it was dedication time. I spent those two months working hard, earning good money that would sustain me for a ridiculous amount of time traveling.

I had found it. A beautiful life hack. Finally I had achieved the ultimate goal, obtaining a US income while living abroad. Not only is it just about the income, it is something that I thoroughly enjoy!

Within three days of being in Lima, I had a revelation. At this point I was very tired of traveling solo. The thought of continuing along my route into Bolivia, Argentina and Chile made me sick to my stomach. I wanted something stable, I was tired of living from my backpack at that point. I was desperately missing my Colombian life.

Due to visa reasons, I stayed in Peru for 3 months before heading back to Colombia via boat in the amazon jungle. After all, just flying from Lima to Medellin would be too easy right? I took the hard route.

I got back into Colombia, and headed back to Medellin after spending a few days in the amazonian town of Leticia. However, my time was limited and I left after just a couple weeks. I headed back down to the coffee region where I have spent the last couple months. Before heading back to the United States, I’m going to spend a couple weeks in Bogota and Tunja to see some friends and Colombian family.

Top 3 Highlights of Year 1

  1. Two months in Medellin

    My time in Medellin was definitely the highlight for me. In those months I became fluent in Spanish, learned how to dance Salsa, Merengue, Bachata and Vallenato to a point where I feel comfortable, and I learned what an awesome city Medellin is.

  2. Colombian Tourism

    Having the privilege of getting to know so many places in Colombia has been quite the opportunity. In the future I would love to do something with tourism in this country, because it is something I’m very passionate about. Showing people this beautiful land is something that I am looking forward to.

  3. Mountains of Ecuador and Peru

    I must say, the mountains of these two countries were incredible. There are some places I want to go back to, and there is still so much more to explore.

Future Plans

So you might be wondering, what’s next?

Well, in a few words, I really don’t know. However, I have a plan.

I’m heading back to the US in a week. I’m going to spend about two months working in Seattle with the client which I have been working remotely with since February, and then probably a few weeks doing other things such as visiting friends and family, hiking, camping, etc.

Then in either October I’m going to head back to Colombia for at least a few months. I’ll probably spend some time back in the Coffee Region and Medellin before heading up to the northern caribbean coast to knock Taganga and La Guajira off the list of places I still need to visit in Colombia.

After that, the travel bug is going to hit me again. I’ll either fly down into patagonia in southern Argentina and Chile and make my way up Chile and Argentina until reaching Bolivia and Southern Peru or I'll head to Brazil and learn portuguese. Still undecided. After that, who knows. I’ll make my way to wherever my little heart desires at the time, which I’m guessing will be back to my beloved Colombia!
fields.headline: What a year it has been
fields.title: One Year in South America
fields.img_alt: Travel South America

fields.body:
I had heard from many people who enjoyed taking the boat trips throughout parts of the Amazon River ranging from Iquitos Peru all the way to Manaus Brazil. After seeing the expensive flights going from Lima to Medellin, I found that flying to Iquitos, taking a boat to Leticia Colombia, and then taking a plane to Medellin was about half the price.

Add in the opportunity to finally go to the Amazon, and it seemed like a win-win situation.

A few days in Iquitos

I flew out to Iquitos and immediately started looking for boats to Leticia but they were hard to come by due to Semana Santa (Easter week). I had to endure three days in Iquitos before I found a boat leaving out of Iquitos.

At that point I desperately wanted to be in Colombia. My last month in Peru was pretty much full of not wanting to be there and just waiting to go back to Colombia. The full reason why I had to wait is complicated, but it was for visa reasons.

I had a hard time sleeping the night before leaving. The night before going to Colombia for me is always like an 8 year old trying to sleep on Christmas Eve. I tossed and turned pretty much all night until finally my alarm went off at 4:45. I’ve never been so excited for an alarm that early in my life.

I made my way to the dock on a mototaxi went through some inspection stuff and then loaded onto the boat. People began to fill the boat and there were two girls somewhere between the ages of 8 and 10 taking pictures with their mom or aunt who was on the boat. I remember those two girls and I have a huge soft spot for latin american kids. They’re ridiculously cute.

Journey on the Amazon

Finally we left for the 10 hour journey along the Amazon stretching from Iquitos to Leticia. I was pumped. I had waited seemingly forever and by the time I got off that boat I would be in Santa Rosa Peru which is pretty much Colombia being only 2 minutes away.

One of my friends had suggested to take the plane because he liked the views better and it was a similar price for just a 1 hour flight. About an hour into the trip, I understood why. I had wanted to take a boat just to say I had taken a boat along the Amazon, but the landscapes were the same for hour after hour.

About 2 hours into the trip we had a big thud that stopped the boat and broke the propeller. We hit one of the trees that were laden throughout the river. For a few seconds it seemed like we were sinking but after about 15 seconds I was convinced we were ok. At this point it was pouring down rain while the 2 crew members worked to replace the propeller.

I thought to myself, what happens if they can’t get it fixed? I would have been so upset having to go back to Iquitos for another day and trying to find a boat or plane again. Luckily, that didn’t happen and we were able to continue along.

There were some russians on the boat, and some type of foreigners in front of me, but everyone else looked amazonian either from Peru, Colombia or Brazil. That included a girl in the front of the boat who had some quite amazing eyes. We made eye contact many many times and each time I became quite distracted.

We continued along the river for many hours and I was following along on the GPS trying to entertain myself by guessing where we would be at certain time intervals and judging when we would arrive to our final destination. Yes, I’m weird like that, but what else is there to do? :)

And then it happened

From my calculations we would have arrived into Leticia at 4:30, and there was only an hour left in the journey. I thought about maybe trying to sleep to speed things up, but it wasn’t working. Things were going really smooth just after our 2nd huge pourdown of rain during the trip. Everything was completely smooth and the people on the boat were quiet.

And then all of a sudden out of nowhere we flipped up onto our side in one fluid motion. For a split second it seemed like maybe we would go on our side but would recover and be fine. However, when water started gushing in through the windows on my side of the boat, within a couple seconds I knew there was no chance of that.

Previously on the boat trip I had thought about something like this happening when our propeller broke and I briefly thought we were sinking. After the boat began to fill, I remember thinking to myself, “wow, this is really happening”. I then heard the boat driver shout something like “Everyone get out of the boat”.

I really only remember about 3 seconds of being in the boat before going under water. After I realized what was happening and heard the captain shout, I remember fully submerging myself, briefly searching for the window and then getting out of it as quickly as I could. I swam up and reached surface and saw the boat slowly moving from being on it’s side to having its stern fully in the water and turning vertical.

Everything for the next few minutes was quite crazy and I could not think very clearly. At that point survival instincts took full control. After popping up in the water and looking for shore, it was far. Very, very, very far. We were at one of the widest parts of the river that I had seen, and we were directly in the middle. I’m a good swimmer and I knew I could probably make it to the shore if needed, but then what? I would have been in the middle of the jungle and would have had to channel my inner Bear Grylls.

I ended up staying by the boat bow which ended up staying afloat for way longer that I had expected. Unfortunately all the life jackets were stuck in the boat and going back in the boat underwater would be quite risky. For someone like me who was a good swimmer, it was not worth the risk.

And then we started to realize that some of us were not there. There were two people who definitely did not know how to stay calm under pressure. One of them was a lady and the other one was a man. The lady started screaming about that there were two kids still in the boat.

Again, at this point it was so hard to think clearly. In my head, I would never have known who was in the boat or who was outside, all I was thinking about was saving my energy in case we needed to swim to shore.

In fact, I couldn’t even remember the kids even though just an hour earlier the little girl was playing with her sister or aunt in the seat next to me. She was super cute and I wanted to take a picture with her, but never did. I didn’t even realize that she didn’t make it out until later that night while trying to sleep, even though there was much talk about two children not making it out.

Looking back at the situation, I only have one thing I would change. I didn’t know the boat bow would stay afloat for 30 minutes. If I had known that I definitely would have attempted to help people out, but I would not have fully gone into the boat. Next time, right?

Sometime in the next 15 minutes we saw something in the window at the front of the boat. With this water it was hard to see a couple inches, but there was definitely something. We were able to open the front window and then someone came out. But it was a corpse. Someone attempted CPR, but at some point it was determined that she wasn’t able to be saved. I then realized, that was the girl I was exchanging eye contact with on the boat ride. This was also the girl that was taking pictures with the kids at the dock in Iquitos.

That’s when it really hit me. People died. Her body was floating right by us. That was the heaviest part of the whole situation. We tied her wrist to a part of the boat so she wouldn’t drift off and then continued trying to get attention.

The Rescue

Finally after about 15 or 20 minutes we saw a boat going by. It was far away but we were yelling and flailing about hopefully they would see us. I noticed I was wearing my bright yellow Colombia soccer jersey so I made sure to keep as much of my torso above the water as possible.

It worked. We were able to get the attention of the tour boat and it changed its course and came directly for us. What a relief that was. I personally didn’t think we would be seeing any boats, especially before the bow of the boat was beneath water and we needed to swim. At this point I any chance of not making it out alive was gone. Losing everything was still a sour idea, but it could have been worse. Really nothing else mattered except for being alive and being able to enjoy the rest of life.

At some point around this time, I saw a black bag floating. I swam closer to it and confirmed, yes, that was my bag! Without my bag, I wouldn’t have had any shoes or any clothes except for what was on my back.

Luckily, I had my James Rodriguez jersey on, which is the most important part of my wardrobe :) That shirt is very significant for me and represents a lot of the love I have for Colombia. Now, it is even that much more special.

Anyway, after the boat arrived they told us there was no room, which was actually true although some people decided to act harshly when they said that, myself include :) They stuck around with us and within 5 to 10 more minutes we were able to wave down two more tour boats who did have room. There were people, bags, and the one body that split up between the three boats and then all headed towards Leticia which was still about an hour away.

The Aftermath

After getting into Leticia, we were dropped off at the dock of the Colombian Coast Guard. There were Colombian Coast Guard, Peruvian Coast Guard, a couple emergency rescue teams, and a few police there ready to greet us. They began getting our names, age and nationalities trying to see how many people survived and how many people were still missing.

In the end, there were 15 survivors including the crew and there were 5 people who did not make it out. I met a guy in my hostel in Leticia who works for Colombia Reports and we went and found out some more information in the next couple days. The Coast Guard ended up finding the body of a pregnant woman, but there were still three bodies missing.

We waited there for things to get sorted out and for bags to arrive. Everyone was obviously very curious of what happened so we spent most of the time explaining the story and theorizing why we flipped. I had to ask about three times “so what are we waiting for now?” Sometimes there was an answer and sometimes there was not.

After immigration showed up and figured out who was staying in Colombia and who was leaving, there wasn’t anything else to wait for. Except for my bag. Myself and an Indian guy’s bags were still missing but were supposedly accounted for at a resort upstream. We had been waiting for the bags to be delivered for around 45 minutes.

Finally the suspense was over and the waterlogged bags were returned to us and it was time to go. The commander of the Colombian Coast Guard in that region ended up giving me a ride into town and dropped me off at the immigration office where a couple very friendly immigration workers met up with me and helped me find a place to stay.

Rolling up to the hostel in the immigration SUV created much curiosity for the hostel guests. They got all excited and thought I had been interrogated or had been smuggling drugs or something like that. They asked me something like “so how did it go in the interrogation room?” I told them It’s better than that and I’ll tell you later while I continued walking to see if there was a bed available, and there ended up being one left.

I got everything into the hostel hung up and drying before making my way back out to the front to tell the people staying in the hostel the full story. They were shocked. The story blew away what they had been thinking.

In the end, I was just happy to be alive, in Colombia and drinking some refreshing Aguila (a Colombian beer). Finally I had made it to Colombia, although this time it was in a manner that I will never forget.
fields.headline: I had heard from many people who enjoyed taking the boat trips throughout parts of the Amazon River
fields.title: Tragedy on the Amazon
fields.img_alt: Boat on the Amazon

fields.body:
The Early Times

It's been a long journey. I'm approaching nearly 3 years since I first decided to focus on learning Spanish, and what an unexpected life-changing journey it has been.

In the beginning I was spending all my time on Livemocha.com doing lessons and chatting with friends whom I met through the website. I was reading 5-6 spanish articles a day, trying to improve as much as I could each and every day. English music went out the window and was replaced with Spanish music. Everything changed.

Days became weeks, and weeks became months. Now, months have become years.

Slowly I began transitioning off the need for Google Translate. My conversations with people on Livemocha became more fluid. My typing improved every day as I absorbed more and more of the most beautiful language in the world. 

After about the first year, I hardly had the need for Google Translate and I began to ask myself - am I fluent with typing and reading?

The Levels of Fluency

Well, the answer was no. Or was it yes? It's really a subjective question and depends on what people consider fluency.

I knew I was not completely fluent, In my head, that part was not debatable. I had so much work to do with speaking and listening because I didn't have as much opportunity to practice those parts of the language. However, my writing and reading was pretty damn close. I still needed to use Google Translate maybe once a day, but I was feeling good. I was feeling fluent.

Looking back, I would not say I was fluent at that time with reading and writing. Nowadays I use Google Translate less than once a month for some obscure word that I have never seen before, and likely won't come up for a long time. I am now fluent, and I'm pretty sure a year from now I will agree with that statement.

The speaking part of Spanish didn't come so quickly, and there were more questions on when I became fluent and even a small inkling of a doubt if I am currently fluent.

At the beginning of my current South America trip, I knew I was not fluent. I was immersing myself day in and day out speaking Spanish and before the trip I had an idea that maybe after a month I would be able to consider myself fluent.

I wouldn't say I achieved that in a month, or even two months. It took a solid 3 months before I began to consider myself fluent. There were many days when I wondered if I was fluent or not and as time progressed it became more difficult to say that I was not fluent.

I began to make less errors. I began to talk quicker. I started receiving more and more compliments. "Oh you're from the US? But why do you speak very good Spanish?". New accents became easier to understand (until I met Chilenos and Argentinos...). 

Little by little I began to consider myself more fluent. But what does that even mean? 

It's about a feeling 

For the first time ever, while writing this article I have decided to turn to my trusty friend Google to get a definition of language fluency. It talks about reading, writing, comprehension, speaking, and reading comprehension. I've found examples such as easily read texts in the language, produce and understand speech, and formulate texts.

As you can see, there's a lot of gray area. And for that reason, I have been confused for so long if I can consider myself fluent.

That is, until now. I think there are a couple aspects of language that are vastly overlooked. It is the feeling you have when using a language and it is how you think when using a language.

To me these are by far the most important parts, and the determining factor in what I personally consider fluency.

I have been able to fulfill some definitions of fluency for quite some time now - especially on the written side. However, I didn't have the feeling.

Now when I speak Spanish, I don't need to think. My mind is completely at ease, and the words just flow out. I never have to translate anything and I have a harder time figuring out how to say things in English rather than how to say things in Spanish.

When people talk to me in English I have to switch my brain over and it feels unnatural, albeit that feeling only lasts for about 5-10 seconds. 

When I talk to myself in my head (or out loud sometimes, but that's a different story...) it is in Spanish. I used to get super excited when I had dreams in Spanish, but now I don't know whether I dream in Spanish or English - it's a mix of both.

After I received that special feeling, I knew I could consider myself fluent. It's been quite a long road over the last 3 years, but it has been the best road I have ever been on.
fields.headline: I've had many definitions while learning Spanish, but I think I have a final answer
fields.title: What is language fluency?
fields.img_alt: What is Language Fluency

fields.body:
During my time in Huanchaco Peru, I had a revelation on the importance and value of time.

My thoughts on the value of time were fueled after I started working on a new project in which I actually get paid. Along with that, overnight, the value of my time instantly skyrocketed.

To be great at something, it takes time. It takes a lot of time. The more time it takes to become great at something, generally correlates closely to how impressive, lucrative, or valued that specific skill is.

Finding the value of time

Many people are going to squawk at the following statement - I learned the value of time through video games. No but wait, hear me out!

Have you ever dedicated yourself to something? Like, completely dedicated yourself? There are varying degrees of "dedication" and I have heard of people who say "Yes, when I was learning spanish I studied for 2 hours every day!". For some people, that is dedication, and for others, that is nothing. Personally, I would ask, what stopped you from studying more?

You see, I'm someone who gets really into things. Like really into things. It's unhealthy. I've gone through phases in my life for my obsessions - videogames, tennis, soccer, spanish, colombia, and now web development. When I enter these "phases", it becomes my life. 

Going back to the first example, I didn't just study Spanish for a certain amount of time per day, I spent almost all my free time devoted to learning Spanish. When I got home from work and/or soccer, I would practice Spanish. When I listened to music at work, it was always in Spanish. When I read news, it was in Spanish. When I dreamt, sometimes it was in Spanish. For some reason I even switched my speedometer to kilometers, but that was a bit overboard and I returned to miles...

My introduction to the value of time began for me around the age of 18 when I started to really get into competitive video games. One of my good friends and his brother for years had always been amazingly good at video games, way better than the rest of us. What was their secret? Well, there was a lot of skill involved which increases efficiency, but the secret to gaining that skill was dedication of time.

I was under the impression that 5-6 hours a day would be sufficient, however, what stopped me from putting in 7-8 hours? Sometimes there are things that limit time such as school or friends, but it all depends on how you value your time and what you want to invest your time into.

I wanted to become great. The competitive nature in me always wanted more. In college I constantly was able to increase my play time and become better and better. I was constantly grinding away, minimizing my time away, and maximizing efficiency while I was playing. During the weekdays I was playing anywhere varying from 8-12 hours and on the weekends I was able to put in around 12-17 hours. Holy smokes, right! Now that is dedication. 

However, as you can imagine, after a couple years I learned that that dedication was not what I wanted to dedicate myself to. Although I have to thank that period of my life, because it taught me the maximum possible level of dedication, as well as taught me the value of time.

How I handle time

After those years with competitive gaming, I have hardly wasted any time. I've always been on the go and always spending my time on what I find to be important. 

For a few months in the spring of 2011 I was working full-time, doing two classes for my MBA, coaching high-school soccer and teaching a fitness class once or twice a week. Those months were crazy, but I had learned how to manage time and work hard and efficiently. After those few months, I felt like I could take on anything and everything. I'm always up for a challenge.
  
I went through phases of tennis where I would watch all the tennis I could and in my free time was down at the park hitting against the wall, playing with people down there, or practicing my serve. That phase only lasted for about 6-8 months, and then my time was taken over by the sport I had played my whole life - soccer. Following that, Spanish was the king and I limited soccer because Spanish became more important.

The secret to all of this was what I learned in the beginning through video games. They introduced me to tru dedication and learning that anything is possible. I hardly wasted any time.

New thoughts on the value of time

I think I've figured out a big part of why people in Latin America are so happy and fulfilled, and a substantial part of it has to do with how they value time.
 
Before I started working on my new project I would spend my days working on Travel Blog Source for about 4-6 hours, go to the beach, take naps and mosey around. I didn't mind how much time things took, and I certainly wasn't concerned about losing time. You see, my time over the past few months was not worth very much. In fact, it wasn't worth anything at all. For that reason I was able to do many things without any need for dedication and without what many people would consider stress.

Think of yourself as a small restaurant owner on a tropical beach. I'm talking really small, a family restaurant which you've been working in since you were a child. People come in everyday and you get them their food in exchange for money. There are no plans of growth or expansion, it's just your family restaurant which was handed down to you from your parents, and you'll hand it down to your children. The money you make supports your family and you're content with that.

There is not much value to time. You can walk around the beach, you can take naps, you can do nothing, you can chat for hours, and there's no loss. You're making maybe $30 per day profit which is plenty to support your family. Sure there are things you can't do, and there is not much opportunity, but what you have you cherish and you're happy staying as-is.

Finding the secret

For some people, that sounds peachy. For myself, I need challenge. It would be hard for me to be content on the tropical beach selling food and drinks. I mean, I think we can admit it would be awesome for a while. But what about after a year? 
 
Different cultures look at this differently, and Americans are notorious for always wanting more. We have a certain competitive drive that is tough for other people to catch up with, and it is something that is in our blood and in our culture. Most of the time we lose sight of that drive because it is just part of us - but my eyes have been opened and I see how different we are. We think differently, we live differently.

There is a saying that goes "the less someone has, the happier they are". This is something that I agree with for the most part, however it does have its flaws.

The secret is value of time. When someone's time is not valuable and they don't have much opportunity to improve their situation, they are happy with what they have. The more opportunity and drive someone has, the more they want. You lose sight of what you have and focus on what you could have in the future. 

There comes a time when you have to decide do you want to be great, or do you want to get by? Do you want to truly dedicate yourself to something? There's nothing wrong with getting by, it's the easier choice. There are many easy opportunities to get by, and they are not bad choices.

A new goal I now have in my life is to be in a situation where my wealth grows without having to invest time. After accomplishing that goal, I would have financial goals taken care of, as well as significantly lowering the value of my time. It's not just about making money, it's about not having to make any more of it and freeing up time.

In the business world, it's called making money while you sleep and these revenue streams are the best ones. Here's the million dollar question - how do I accomplish this goal? I have many options, and none of them involve taking an easy route. If they were easy, everyone would be rich, and no one would have to be great at what they do.
fields.headline: How much is time really worth?
fields.title: Value of Time
fields.img_alt: value of time

fields.body:
Honestly, the only reason I'm traveling is because I can only stay 6 months in Colombia. From the minute I stepped foot outside of Colombia, everything changed.

Today I have had a lot of time to think, and that thinking has resulted in my realization that I really don't want to continue south solo traveling. Solo traveling really isn't for me. I have so much flexibility, can make all decisions, can travel cheaply, but the memories and experiences just aren’t the same.

Technically, Lima would probably be the best place to cut off my trip. I could finish traeling from Lima south some other time. It really wouldn't be that bad, and I could bring along a special someone. I'd definitely enjoy that more than solo long-term traveling.

I began thinking about what if I return to Colombia tomorrow? I began looking at flights from Lima to Bogota or Medellin. I began looking at apartment postings in my beautiful Medellin.

Just the thought alone of Colombia makes me giddy. I just got goosebumps writing that last sentence. Seriously, I have problems. The thought of going back to Colombia has consumed my thoughts.

What are the choices I have?

The way I see it, I have 3 choices. There are also a couple "static" things that are set in stone (albeit, soft stone). I can't plan on being in Colombia for more than 6 months. I will be in Colombia for the World Cup from mid-June until mid-July. I will be in the United States from late July until early September.

Option #1 - Return to Colombia now

I found a ticket in 4 days for just over $400. If I returned now, that puts me at just under 5 months in Colombia and I could return for December (the best month), and until June 30th of the next year.

The problem with this option is that I wouldn't get to fully experience Lima, and honestly it seems like the best place I've been to since I left Cali, Colombia. If I continue struggling to find a place to stay in Lima, I might go with this option. Oh man, I get excited just thinking about this option :)

Option #2 - Return to Colombia in 1-3 months

Ok, I could stay in Lima for now. I continue searching for a place, and can stay here for a couple months. I would then return to Colombia in mid-April, stay for 3 months, and then return for 3 months later in the year.

The reason why this is good is that it gives me 9 consecutive months in Colombia. That's a lot of time without having to leave, which would be amazing. Heavenly, one might say.

Another pro to this option is that I would get to fully experience Lima, and when I return in the future it would just be to visit and begin a trip from Lima south.

Option #3 - Continue my travel plans

Maybe I don't go back to Colombia early. Maybe I continue traveling south after spending a month in Lima. As of today, this option is definitely my last choice. Who knows how I will feel tomorrow though, I certainly don't.

The thought of me leaving Lima and traveling all the way down to central Chile, over into Argentina and Uruguay just doesn’t excite me. It’s not what I want to do right now. I’m “fine” in Lima, but continuing my travels south is looking bleak.
fields.headline: Having some serious thoughts about not continuing south.
fields.title: Am I done traveling for now?
fields.img_alt: Lima Peru

fields.body:
First stop in Peru - Piura

Getting into Peru was about as easy as it gets. The luck-bug bit me hard - I got on a bus from Loja Ecuador to the border with Peru, and it just so happened that the bus continued through the border all the way to Piura, my final destination.

I'd heard bad stories about the Peru-Ecuador border and I was told to be careful and aware. In fact, I'd met a Belgian in Cuenca who had been robbed at knifepoint on the Peru side of the border and he ended up losing $600. Why you would carry $600 (and not even hide it is beyond me.

Crossing the less-traveled mountain crossing was a totally different story. It took only about 5 minutes and was about as safe as can be.

Apparently the beautiful scenery of Ecuador stopped at Loja. The bus-ride to the border was quite ugly, and frankly, depressing. It gave me the same feeling I get while driving through parts of eastern Oregon actually - full of desolation, nothingness, and completely dry.

I got into Piura just after nightfall and had a taxi ride around to find a hostel. There wasn't anything that looked too promising, and after walking around the hostel district and checking out 4 hostels, I decided to pick one.

Bad choice, however, they were all bad. The hostel I stayed at was the worst place I have ever stayed.

When showing me the room, I instantly noticed how hot it was, however the guy pointed out that there was a fan. Ok, that should be fine, right?

We went back down, and I paid the $7 for the room. After going back up and checking out the ugly, dirty room, I tried to turn on the fan. It didn't work. I went back down to tell them that the fan didn't work, I couldn't sleep in that hot box, and that I needed my money back. They looked at each other and said I had already registered and paid so they couldn't give me my money back. I made some rude gestures and statements showing my displeasure, but they didn't seem to mind.

After what I had seen of Piura on the first night, there was no way I was staying for any extended time. In fact, the next morning I decided to leave and head south to Trujillo. Twelve hours in Piura was more than sufficient.

Trujillo/Huanchaco

The 6 hours from Piura to Trujillo was another 6 hours of nothingness, desolation and desert (besides passing through a town called Chiclayo). On the plus side, the bus was the best bus I had ever ridden in and was great for sleeping.

I got into Trujillo and took a taxi down to a beach called Huanchaco - this time, I had done my research and found a good place I wanted to go to.

As soon as I got into Huanchaco my mood was lifted. The sunny beach town was something I desperately needed after Piura. I got in on a Sunday and the beach was absolutely packed full of Peruvians who were there to enjoy the weekend. It made for a good entrance.

Beach town of Huanchaco

The hostel I arrived to was in fact a good one, and the first thing I noticed was that the room was not scorching hot and I would actually be able to sleep there. YES!

Combined with the great internet, and even better ambiance of the small beach town, Huanchaco was a great place to stay for a week or two and get some quality work done.

The weather in Huanchaco was almost perfect. I stayed there 10 days and it not once rained, and was never cold. I wore flip-flops, shorts, and never needed a shirt the entire time. I never needed pants either, but I probably needed to find a different beach for that.

Around Trujillo there are a couple ancient ruins from the people who lived there before the Incas overcame them. The most famous place to go to in Trujillo for tourists is a place called Chan Chan which is more or less a "giant sand castle".

Ruins of Chan Chan

Walking through the ruins of Chan Chan gave perspective to a totally different way of life. It's interesting how even before the Spanish arrived and ridded the Incas of all their power, the Incans had their own foreign people close to them.

The time spent in Huanchaco was well worth it. It was a much needed break from some rough stays in Loja and Piura. But hey, not everywhere can be great.

My plan was to head to Huaraz after Trujillo, but after all the good things people said about Cajamarca I needed to check it out. So now I'm writing this article on the bus on the way to Cajamarca!
fields.headline: Deserts and Beaches in northern Peru
fields.title: Two weeks in Northern Peru
fields.img_alt: Northern Peru Beach

fields.body:
Cotopaxi

From Quito I took a van ascending the mountains to the east of Quito making way up to the region near Ecuador's most famous mountain - Cotopaxi.

Cotopaxi is a mountain I had been looking at for a while and knew it was one of the top places I wanted to go to in Ecuador.

I had hope the journey up into the mountains would be a much needed escape from Quito after a rough first week in Ecuador.

After the short two hour trip (I'm now very accustomed to long bus rides), we arrived to the Secret Garden Hostel just a half hour away from the Cotopaxi National Park.

What an amazing place. I had heard from numerous people that Secret Garden Cotopaxi was their favorite hostel in South America, and I quickly learned why.

The feeling you get while at Secret Garden is hard to explain, but the words that come to mind are serenity, peace, and tranquility. Away from everything, Secret Garden offers a unique experience which is hard to find anywhere else.

Having beautiful views over the valley and vistas of 7 volcanoes from their property, they are located on prime grounds. Unfortunately, the three days I was there I never saw any of them - it was cloudy the entire time. Luckily I was still able to see the lower valley, which made the trip worth it. I can only imagine how beautiful it would have been with the volcanoes towering above.

I took a few hikes close to the cabin, however the main attraction was to climb the base of Cotopaxi. With some of the fellow hostel-mates we took a van into the national park of Cotopaxi and began our guided hike from the trailhead. Again, it was cloudy the entire time and we never were able to actually see the mountain. They say it actually is there though, and I think I trust them.

While we climbed up in the brisk mountain air starting at 15,000+ feet it began to hail. Some of the people I was with had never seen snow before, so I let them know that a little bit higher the hail would stop and it would begin to snow. Literally 20 steps later, I was a prophet.

Something that has always interested me is Latin American’s fascination with snow. Sometimes fish fail to see the water, and after years, we fail to see the snow. It really is quite an amazing thing and that I've learned from the people who have never seen snow before.

Anyway, we kept trudging our way up in the falling snow and inevitably a snowball fight broke out. If you're guessing that I started the snowball fight, you would be right. I also taught them how to make a snowman, and that kept us amused for about half an hour.

After making our way up past a refuge, we arrived to the first glacier base at 5,000 meters (16,500ft+) before descending back down. As we made our way back down, the snow became rain and was far less enjoyable.

Baños

A few days after arriving to Secret Garden Cotopaxi, it was time to continue south to a town called Baños de Agua Santa, or Baños for short.

Alongside Montañita, Baños is one of the two major touristy areas in Ecuador. The streets are packed full of hostels, restaurants and souvenir shops and I quickly saw how tourism totally controls the city.

Usually I don't like touristy areas (the reason I didn't go to Montañita), however I had a good feeling about Baños. There are many activities such as rafting, rappelling, bungee, biking, hiking, and more. Sitting in a large river valley that cuts into the tall Ecuadorian mountains, Baños is not short on beautiful views.

Probably my favorite activity there was when I went hiking up in the mountains and ended up losing myself - mostly on purpose.

However, after about 5 days in Baños, I was ready to leave. It was nice for a few days, but after walking around the whole city multiple times and doing the touristy activities that drew my attention, there wasn't much else to do.

Cuenca

Continuing south, another 10 hours in bus awaited me. After the first few minutes in Cuenca, I knew I would be staying there for longer than a few days.

I have to admit, Cuenca was my favorite place in Ecuador - I can see why it is the most famous place for Americans to retire. The weather was nice there, a much needed break from the colder weather in northern and central Ecuador.

It was cleaner, more modern, and more organized than the other places I had been to in Ecuador. It kind of had a small feel of Medellin in that sense. However, it was much quieter and well... not as exciting, beautiful, or warm as Medellin :)

Full of churches, colonial streets and housing, Cuenca was the most impressive city I went to in Ecuador. Walking the streets takes you back in time and definitely adds some much needed variety to life.

The 'highlight' of Cuenca was a daytrip to El Cajas National Park which is only about an hour outside of Cuenca.

The high andean climate boasts some unique landscapes and plants. We made our way through the park visiting various lakes, forests, muddy obstacles and constantly going up and down hills.

We ended up hitchhiking back in the back of a truck where I ended up leaving my gray nike small backpack which I've had for years. Fortunately I didn't have anything except shorts, but that bag was very handy and special to me - you've probably seen many pictures with me using it on all my hikes.

Final Thoughts on Ecuador

After about a week in Cuenca I was ready to head to Peru. I could have stayed in Cuenca longer, but I had plans in Lima to travel with a friend and needed a few weeks in northern Peru before heading south to Lima.

I stopped by Loja in southern Ecuador and had plans to visit a few places close to Loja, but I was not especially keen on the city and after only 1 night decided to leave.

My final thoughts on Ecuador unforutunately are not the best. It is a beautiful country with some very impressive landscapes. In fact, other than Costa Rica and Switzerland, it might be the third most beautiful country I’ve been to.

Putting its beauty aside, for the most part I was not too fond of the culture or people I encountered. Maybe the coast is different, but in the mountains it was quite quiet, tame and a little boring. Many people (mostly in the north) seemed to treat me differently, more like a extranjero than a person. Aka, they just wanted my money and didn't care about giving a good experience or impression.

Ecuador's tourism level is high, especially in the few places I went to. Many people had an attitude similar to the costal Colombians where it was almost like when you go to a restaurant they didn't want to serve you and it was just an obligation to them. However, it was not as bad as coastal Colombia.

Honestly, I do take the majority of the blame for these negative thoughts. I came into Ecuador and was not mentally or emotionally ready to leave my beloved Colombia. I am almost 100% confident that if I return to Ecuador I would have a better opinion of it.
fields.headline: Cotopaxi, Baños, Cuenca, Loja
fields.title: Three weeks through Ecuador
fields.img_alt: Ecuador

fields.body:
Now that I’m making my way through South America, I’ve noticed some recurring ideas that other travelers have about Colombia.

I’m not going to lie, being in Colombia for so long has built a biased view of what I think travelers think of Colombia. The travelers who venture their way into Colombia already have a certain idea of the country and know enough about the current situation and feel comfortable enough to enter.

Just about all travelers I met in Colombia had a positive experience and a positive opinion about Colombia. I even met a slew of foreigners who decided to make Colombia their home, especially in Medellin.

However, what I didn’t know was what travelers outside of Colombia thought about the country.

Favorite country is Colombia, or all of South America!

In Colombia, in 5 months I met countless people who had traveled through all of South America and their favorite country was Colombia.

I once learned about the pride that Colombians felt when they learned I had a favorable opinion about their country. Now a days, I feel the same pride when I talk to foreigners that have the same favorable opinion.

Equally as surprising as the amount of travelers that preferred Colombia was the lack of loyalty travelers had to other countries. Almost half the people that traveled all of South America said they liked Colombia more than the rest, and the other half said each country had their own thing they liked.

Now that I’m outside of Colombia, things have changed because I meet many travelers that have not been to Colombia. In fact, many travelers don’t even have plans of going.

Should I go to Colombia?

After I got into Ecuador a couple things caught me off guard - the amount of people who didn’t have plans to go to Colombia, and the sheer amount of tourists in Ecuador.

I thought Colombia was doing well in tourism, but now I see there is still much more progress to be had. Ecuador has towns full of tourists. If you go to places like Baños de Agua Santa or Montañita, you will be inundated by tourists. There isn’t too much culture to be experienced in these places unless you make an intention to find it.

There are some places in Colombia such as the old town in Cartagena, Poblado in Medellin, and La Candelaria in Bogota which some might argue are comparable, but I disagree. The closest is the walled city of Cartagena, as Poblado and Candalaria are both filled with locals as well as tourists.

I found out that Colombia still was the hidden gem of South America, and I also learned that many people still are hesitant about going to the country.

When making plans to traverse South America, it’s astonishing the amount of people who stop at Ecuador.

Generally people aren’t familiar with what’s in Colombia and it gets overshadowed by the rich tourism history of Ecuador and Peru. Many people just simply overlook Colombia.

Is Colombia dangerous?

Above other opinions, people still tend to ask if Colombia is dangerous. Admittedly, there is quite a bit to see in South America and the easy choice is to take the more known route.

Without much research, people can venture from Argentina to Ecuador based on their reputation alone. We all know what happens to reputation when you get to Colombia - it dive bombs.

The fact is that I have so much time invested into researching and reading about Colombia. I know the ins and outs. I know the few dangerous spots, and I know what to avoid. Sometimes I forget how much I know about the country, it is a part of me now.

It does take a bit of research and for that reason many people don’t make the journey across the border into Colombia. It’s easier to stick to the known.

The future of tourism in Colombia

From my limited experience in South America outside of Colombia, I can’t help but think about the future of tourism in Colombia.

Almost everyone that goes to Colombia loves it there, but still a surprising number of people don’t make their way into the country. As the years go by, tourism in Colombia is going to keep growing. Even in the two and a half years I have been learning about Colombia, I have seen tourism grow.

Well folks, I have some insider news. It’s going to keep growing. I’m already thinking about how to help tourism grow, and realize opportunities that will arise from the growth in tourism.
fields.headline: I've noticed some recurring ideas about Colombia from fellow travelers
fields.title: 3 Common Thoughts On Colombia

fields.body:
As each day passes, my idea of long-term travel becomes clearer.

Everyone who chooses a life of long-term travel does it in different ways. Admittedly, my style of long-term travel is a tad watered down compared to others because right now I do have plans to stop traveling after about a year, however that plan could change tomorrow.

True long-term travel does not have an end. There's still possibility to continue my travel for years, and I am still working on location independent income, however my love for Colombia is most likely going to get in the way.

That being said, out of all the people I meet while traveling, it's quite rare to meet people who are traveling for as long as I am. Now that we're in tourism high-season, the number of normal vacationers has skyrocketed, but in the next few months during low-season there will be many people who have chosen a similar lifestyle to that which I have chosen.

I get asked many of the same questions when people find out that I'm traveling for 1-X years; for many “normal” people this is something completely exotic. When I first started learning about this lifestyle, I asked the same eager questions.

But how do you get money? Are you traveling alone? What do your parents think? Rarely people ask me questions that I have yet to hear, and I always get excited having to think about an answer that I haven't given 20 times before.

What is long-term travel?

For me, long-term travel means a slew of things. It is about choosing a challenging lifestyle that is not the norm. It is about broadening vision on life through discovering new places and cultures that would not have been possible with a normal life. It is about letting yourself go and being free in the world.

The normal lifestyle is what we grew up thinking was the template for our life. You go to school, you get a job, you start buying stuff, you make a family, and then you teach your children the same way of life. This, my friends, is the easy route.

Long-term travel requires taking more risk, and a bit more imagination and ingenuity. Taking a few years off sets back your career, and sets back what many would consider success. People will advance their careers while you're off gaining new perspectives on life. Almost all people who are interested in this lifestyle stop here - it really is quite frightening taking the next step.

But why do people always suggest traveling when you're young and taking a few years off of your career? The answer is because they did not take the risk when they were younger, but now wish that they did. They passed a certain point in their life (usually involving a spouse and kids) where they can no longer travel freely.

Gaining life perspective from culture

A life based around travel introduces you to many different types of people from around the world, and can introduce you to new cultures and ways of thinking.

I've always been a person who thinks in the big picture. I don't just want to create a travel blog, I want to create a way to improve the world of travel blogs. I don't want to just donate to a good cause, I want to create a good cause and have others donate. I don't want to just create websites for people, I want to create a new way of developing websites. If I have interest in something, I rarely take the easy route. It’s just too mundane!

Most importantly, on a personal note, I don't want to just have a normal life, I want to have an interesting life outside the box. Because of that, after I conquered the easy route, I needed a challenge.

Growing up in the United States, we're taught a certain template in life that we're supposed to follow if we want to be successful (aka happy). However, other cultures do not think the same way, and the more people I meet while traveling the more options I learn about for what I want to do with my life.

There are simple choices and there are complex choices. There are easy choices and there are difficult choices. There are interesting choices and there are boring choices. Everything is a mix of these aspects, and long-term travel is definitely not down the easy, simple, or boring path.

Freedom in life

Long-term travel opens the flood gates to discover what life is really about. Many times I go places without a plan. My schedule changes on a daily basis and as each day passes I have the opportunity to change anything.

Just yesterday I met some Colombians while climbing Cotopaxi and would like to spend some time with them, so now I might be modifying my travel route, because I can. I have no set agenda, only an idea. I can go wherever, whenever.

However, the freedom is more than just in travel. I can work on projects, relax, stress, pick my nose, climb mountains, swim in lakes, anything. I can stop and find a job, I can continue traveling, I can stay with a family, I can couchsurf, I can stay in hostels. Each day is different, and much of my direction is determined by the people I meet each and every day. I have almost total freedom to do whatever floats my boat on a daily basis.

Related Post Life as a Working Traveler

Right now there is one main restriction, and that is money. I'm still working on gaining a positive location independent income and working while traveling, and that is the challenge I need. I'm someone who always needs a good challenge to work towards, and without this challenge I would wilt. I found that out within my first month of this trip.

Not everyone is like that however, and everyone thinks differently. I'd love to hear your opinion on long-term travel!
fields.headline: As each day passes, my idea of long-term travel becomes clearer
fields.title: What is Long Term Travel?
fields.img_alt: Long Term Travel

fields.body:
#5 Bucaramanga

Starting off the list is Bucaramanga which is the main city in the Santander province.

First of all, one of the major highlights of Bucaramanga is the weather. Especially if you’re coming from Bogota or anywhere in Boyaca, you will be pleasantly surprised by the warmth.

Unfortunately I was only in Bucaramanga for a few busy days, so I wasn’t able to explore too much, however the city left a memorable experience for me and I would love to go back some day to get to know the city a little bit more.

Around Bucaramanga there are a few must sees such as Chichamocha Canyon and San Gil. Unfortunately I haven’t been to San Gil yet, but I have heard many great things from other travelers and next time I go back to Bucaramanga I will not miss it.

Wedding in Bucaramanga

#4 Bogota

People tend to either love or hate Bogota. Most of the time, to be honest, people hate it. Bogota will always have a special place in my heart because it was the first place I went to in Colombia and where I spent most of my time the first 2 trips to Colombia.

Bogota is a lot bigger than people realize. With around 8 million people, only São Paolo of Brazil has more people in South America. There really is a lot to explore in Bogotá, but unfortunately many people only hit the touristy spots.

It is not the cleanest city. You will find many dirty areas, shady areas, and it’s possible to find yourself in some dangerous areas as well. However, everything you would want to see in Bogotá is generally located in safe areas, the dangerous areas have back backed away into areas where there really is nothing to see.

For me, Bogotá is the most real city. You will find many different cultures in Bogotá, many of which are not replicated anywhere else in Colombia. There is so much to see in the vast city, and if you like to explore the unknown and experience real culture, you will enjoy Bogotá as much as I do.

#3 Cartagena

Cartagena sees more tourism than any other Colombian city, and for good reason. The old walled city of Cartagena is interesting, exciting, beautiful, and unique.

Where else can you go to find an old historical, colorful, walled city with plenty of attractions to keep people busy for a few days? Let me know if you know another one, I’d like to go there.

There is plenty to see and do within the walled city city, most of which involves walking around all the eloquent shops, seeing the beautiful colonial buildings, and visiting museums to learn about the fascinating walled city of Cartagena.

In addition, you’re also smack dab in the middle of the caribbean coast weather which makes for the perfect place for a winter excursion.

#2 Pereira

Centrally located in the coffee region, there is much to see in Pereira and its surroundings.

Inside of the city there are a few attractions such as la Circunvalar, central plaza, Jardin Botanico, and various viewpoints of the city. Many people refer to Pereira as a “little Medellin” because it offers friendly paisas as well as a favorable climate, but is a smaller city with less hustle and bustle. It certainly provided some much needed warmth after spending some time in the nearby mountain towns of Manizales and Salento.

Related Post Top 5 Nature Spots in Colombia

Inside of the city is just the start. As mentioned a couple of paragraphs ago, it is located in the center of the coffee region and is also the largest city of the region. There is so much to explore around the city such as Salento, Valle de Cocora, Santa Rosa de Cabal, various pueblos, Coffee Park in Montenegro, Armenia, and so much more. I highly recommend staying in Kolibri Hostel when you go to Pereira and the people there are super friendly and will help you figure out nearby attractions.

#1 Medellin

And we’ve arrived to my favorite city in Colombia - beautiful Medellin. I don’t even know where to start with Medellin, and I get goosebumps just thinking about the city.

The weather is absolutely perfect in my opinion, and according to many other people. There’s really not much else to say, you just have to go to understand. Having perfect weather each and every day really makes life easy to enjoy, even if it’s not going that well!

Medellin is the most lively city I have ever been to. There are countless events which happen almost every single day, and best of all, most of them are free. The events range from afro-colombian music festivals, to craft fairs, to live music festivals.

Medellin surpassing my expectations

Christmas in Medellin
