fields.body:
The Journey to Ecuador

Starting off, getting to Ecuador from Colombia was quite the adventure. I started the day off in Cali Colombia and because it was peak season, finding a ticket south was quite the challenge.

Scouring almost all the companies in the Cali bus terminal, after an hour of searching almost all companies said they were sold out until January 5th. It was seeming like I would be stuck in Cali an extra day.

Luckily, I found an ecuadorian couple who were trying to head south as well, and we quickly joined forces and started searching together.

A miracle happened and we found some tickets to Pasto Colombia which is only about 2 hours from the Ecuadorian border. Perfect.

After a 10 hour, cramped bus ride, we arrived to Pasto just a little bit short of midnight. Now what? I had no plans and had no idea where I'd end up.

Along with my Ecuadorian friends, we found some other people in the Pasto bus terminal who were intending to go to Ecuador and after about an hour we formed a hodge-podge group of 12 people, which is what a van driver told us was needed to go to the Ecuadorian border. There were no more buses heading towards Ecuador for the night, so that was our only hope.

Another couple hours passed and we approached the border of Ecuador. Finally! We powered through the border, which had no line at 2am, and the Ecuadorians ended up staying the night in the Ecuadorian border town as I continued on a bus to Quito.

Bus ride from Quito to Otavalo

First day in Ecuador

The ride from the border town of Tulcan to Quito is about 5 hours, so that put me into the Carcelen Quito Bus Terminal around 8 in the morning. I didn't even know I would end up in Quito, let alone where I would stay. So... it was time to find wifi and do some reasearch.

No luck.

I searched and asked and searched and asked, but there was no wifi in the bus terminal nor wifi within a few block radius. So, I had to abandon my plans to do my own research and rely on the advice of a couple taxi drivers which told me a neighborhood which had plenty of hostels to choose from called Mariscal.

After a rather expensive taxi ride, I arrived to a super touristy, expensive neighborhood which is exactly not what I search for. However, I was glad to finally arrive to a place where I could rest and relax after the 18 hour impromptu excursion from Cali to Quito.

Another curveball was thrown my direction. After asking 5 or 6 hostels, no one had availability. Damn tourism high-season!

I found a rather dodgy looking hostel (everything is a bit dodgy in Quito) who had availability and I quickly secured that up for a night.

I had full intention of leaving Quito the next day. I was not feeling it, and I had not heard good things from friends either.

Looking back, I think I was a bit judgemental about Quito. Coupled with my sadness of leaving Colombia, my preconceived conception of Quito didn't give the city any chance. One day I think I'll return with a fresh mindset and see if it is any different. A less-touristy area would help as well.

The rest of the day was relaxed and I just chatted with people in the hostel to recover from the long journey. I met a german friend who had been living in Ecuador for a few months doing volunteer work and had the same love for Ecuador as I had for Colombia. She was heading to Otavalo (a town north of Quito famous for their indiginous handicraft market) to meet some friends and I decided to join her and check it out as well.

Otavalo

After a 30 minute taxi ride and a 2 hour bus ride we arrived to the town of Otavalo. Indigenous mecca! I'd never seen so many indigenous in my life and it was a unique experience.

We walked around the town and I found out the friends of my german friend had been traveling around for years, and that I was traveling with a clown and a mime! I also found out they ran out of money and needed to work that day, and was lucky enough to watch the mime's performance which was very amusing. He had been doing this for over 20 years, and I could tell.

Performace in the Otavalo market
The market was full of all sorts of handicrafts with the vast majority made by indigenous people who lived in and around Otavalo. Everything from hats to blankets to hammocks to trinkets to countless other things could be found. I wasn't looking to spend any money, however the two german girls I was with ended up buying about 15 items, including a new bag they needed to carry all their stuff! :)

Handicraft market in Otavalo Ecuador

After a couple hours of strolling through the market we went to a market to purchase items for dinner. We found some vegetables, fruits, bread and wine. There would be 11 of their friends staying at our $2/night hostel and we were going to make some sort of fruit/vegetable concoction.

We made our way to the hostel outside of town which was a colorful place with a fantastic view. It was far from a normal hostel which I was accustomed to, but overall it was a good experience. There was no hot water, no wifi, and it was more or less a shack with an outdoor kitchen for us to cook. I'm used to cheap hostels, but this was pushing the limit. What it lacked in accommodation, it was rich in character. At $2/night, it would suffice for a couple days.

Cheap hostel just outside of Otavalo

We chatted throughout the evening with an eclectic group of, for lack of a better term, hippies mainly from Germany and France. Some people were busy cooking dinner while other people were busy making little handicrafts, similar to those that we saw in the market!

The next day, after a cancelled hike to Laguna Cuicocha, I headed back to Quito to spend a night before heading off to Cotopaxi, the most famous mountain in Ecuador.

Thoughts on Ecuador

I'm not sure how clouded my mind is from my Colombia withdrawals, or if I've been affected by other people's opinions of Ecuador, but my first few days in Ecuador have been rough.

I keep comparing everything to Colombia, and nothing seems to match up well.

The buildings and structures gray and dreary. The colorful architecture of Colombia (with some exceptions, especially Bogota) had been replaced by more depressing buildings. Maybe it would be just the parts I've been to the first couple days, who knows?

The uplifting Colombian rhythms of salsa, merengue and vallenato have disappeared. The music here has a different feel to it, and it doesn't give me the same happiness as the Colombian music I have been accustomed to. On the plus side, I have been hearing more bachata, which is something I wish was more popular in Colombia.

The people are different. They just simply aren't as friendly. People don't look at me and smile. When I ask for directions, they don't seem interested in helping. When I greet people, they don't share the same excitement as seen in Colombians. There are many other reasons, and it's just so hard to put into words. Above everything else, I have really missed the Colombian people.

I've only been to a few places in Ecuador, and admittedly I think the best places (Cotopaxi, Baños, Cuenca) are yet to come. I have a lot of hope that my opinion and experience of Ecuador will change in the next few weeks. I really feel I'm just a bitter about leaving my beloved Colombia. We'll see how it goes!
fields.headline: Starting off, getting to Ecuador from Colombia was quite the adventure
fields.title: First Impressions of Ecuador
fields.img_alt: View of Quito Ecuador

fields.body:
#5 Quimbaya Otun

Starting off the list is the wilderness of Quimbaya Otun. These paths are far from the beaten path and you won’t find too many tourists (or even Colombians!) who venture up to the Laguna Otún which sits at over 12,000 feet.

If you’re looking for something off the beaten path, this place will be the best for you. You can enjoy the serenity and solidarity of the peaceful Quimbaya Otun Regional Park. Just make sure to be ready for a journey!

More on Quimbaya Otun Hiking



#4 San Andres

Boasting what many would consider to be the best beaches in Colombia, San Andres offers the best option for a true caribbean get-a-way. If you have a few extra days to spare, you can also visit the nearby Providencia, however I was not able to make the boat ride over to the neighbor island.

All around the island are attractions such as snorkeling, scuba, and my personal favorite - walking around and having a few drinks on the beach.

The pristine beaches and warm caribbean weather will be something you remember, and I guarantee there will not be a shortage of photo opportunities!

More on San Andres



#3 Chicamocha Canyon

Cutting through the arid terrain, the Chicamocha River has carved a beautiful canyon just south of Bucaramanga.

Going to the canyon, I had a perception that there wouldn’t be much to it, and we would go to the top, take some pictures, and that would be that. However, I was greatly surprised by a well-developed park with many attractions that improved the experience of Chicamocha Canyon.

More on Chicamocha Canyon



#2 Rio Claro

The Rio Claro Nature Preserve sits about 3 hours east of Medellin and boasts some of the most breathtaking jungly experiences in Colombia.

With a brilliant green river curving its way through the dense antioqueñan jungle, Rio Claro presents some landscapes which are tough to come across. Also, the nature preserve is decently well developed and offers activities such as rafting, adventure through the Cave of Guacharos, and rock climbing/rappelling.

More on Rio Claro



#1 Valle de Cocora

In the famous coffee region of Colombia lies a small town called Salento. All around Salento are unforgettable mountain landscapes which I consider to be the best in Colombia.

Just a short ride from Salento is the gem of the coffee region - the Cocora Valley. The vast valley filled with unique wax palm trees will leave a lasting memory after you visit. Accompanied with the fresh mountain air, a tour of the Cocora Valley is an absolute must when you have a chance to visit Colombia.

More on Valle de Cocora and Salento



Close Calls

There are a few memorable places that did not quite make my top 5 list such as Parque Tayrona, Salt Cathedral of Zipaquirá, Guatavita, and a few others I’m sure I’m forgetting.

Related Post Top 5 Colombian Cities

Places to see in the future

Of course, there are still many nature spots I have yet to discover, and those are obviously not a part of this list. The places that still have a chance to one day make this list are La Guajira, Islas de Rosario, Leticia, and Desert of Tatacoa. Let me know if there is something that is not in my top 5 list or in the list of places I haven’t been to yet. I’d love to hear about other places and there is always more to explore in Colombia!
fields.headline: Colombia is a beautiful country with plenty to explore
fields.title: My Top 5 Colombia Nature Spots
fields.img_alt: Top 5 Nature Places in Colombia

fields.body:
Colombia is known to go overboard with their Christmas decorations. From the large cities, to the small pueblos - everyone partakes in the festivities.

December in Colombia is a magical time. For those of you who are thinking about visiting Colombia, December is definitely the best time. The whole country has a different feel when it is decked out with Christmas lights.

Medellin takes it one step further. Not only do they have all the normal lights scattered about buildings, parks, and anything else lights can be applied to, but each year they have about a mile-long stretch of the river that they go completely overboard with.

Christmas lights in Medellin
The Alumbrados packed full of paisas on Christmas night
Paisas playing in the lit-up water

Luckily, this year I was able to experience Christmas in Medellin. I spent Christmas with the family that I had been staying with for two months from mid-September until mid-November.

We spent the night dancing away to the the addicting latin rhythms of salsa, merengue, and vallenato. From about 11pm until 3:30 in the morning we were all dancing together in the living room with the whole family.

Christmas tree and nativity scene in the house of my paisa family

A few days before Christmas I wanted to check out Envigado, which is a neighborhood that I needed to investigate to see if I would like to live there if/when I return to Medellin permanently.

It just so happened that there was a big music festival in the main park of Envigado and it was packed full of people.

The streets were lined with lighting hanging side to side above, and the park was completely lit up from the trees, to a large tree made of lights, to the main church.

Huge Christmas tree and church in Parque Envigado
fields.headline: Colombia is known to go overboard with their Christmas decorations; Medellin takes it a step further
fields.title: Christmas in Medellin
fields.img_alt: Christmas lights in Medellin

fields.body:
If you are looking for something off the beaten path, have I got a treat for you.

Hidden away way up in the mountains near Pereira in the coffee triangle region of Colombia lies a lake called Laguna Otún. Getting to the lake is not the easiest journey, hence the reason it is off the beaten path.

Day 1

Starting from Pereira, you need to take a chiva (special Colombian bus) that goes past the pueblo La Florida, and then through a dirt road which ends at a place called El Cedral. The chiva ride alone from Pereira takes a little more than an hour, but it is the only public transportation that will get you that far into the mountains.

The chiva only runs a few times a day, and unfortunately I wasn’t able to catch it. Normal buses only go to La Florida so I ended up having to walk from La Florida to el Cedral, tacking on an extra 12km to my hike.

From La Florida the walk to El Cedral took about two and a half hours through some beautiful country and then through some densely covered forest roads.

Walk through rolling hills from La Florida
Walking on a long road from La Florida to El Cedral

Eventually the road ended and I arrived to a couple structures, which the two French tourists I met told me that the place was indeed El Cedral.

The walk up to this point was rainy, but through the dirt road it wasn’t a tough walk. That would dramatically change after El Cedral.

The rain intensified, and the narrow path turned into a small makeshift river. Jumping from rock to rock trying not to soak my shoes worked out well for a while, but in this 5km stretch it didn’t take long before slipping into the mud and streaming water ridded my desire to keep my feet dry and clean.

The sign wants me to go where??
Is this a path or a stream?

In the past I would have been stressed out about the rain and having everything wet, however in these days I appreciate the more 'difficult' memories almost more than the positive ones. They’re more memorable and meaningful!

Eventually I escaped the thick forest and came into a clearing in which sat a cottage named Ceilan where I bought a coffee and cheese. This was the first time where the view opened up and I was able to see the beauty of the backcountry mountains in the Quimbaya Otún regional park.

Finca El Ceilan

After finishing my snack at the cottage, I made the last 30 minutes of the river-rock-hopping 'hike' and found La Pastora - the cottage that I would be staying at. Luckily I arrived right on time - 15 minutes of daylight left.

View from La Pastora

La Pastora is a well-built, beautiful mountain cottage that can host people as well as provide food. There is no other place that can host people this deep into the Quimbaya Otún wilderness, so it’s essential to stay there if you’re wanting to make it to the Laguna Otún which is sits at over 12,000 feet.

With no electricity in the cottage, and only a few candles to provide light, there wasn’t much to do after dark. After eating a typical home-cooked Colombian dinner, I went to bed early in preparation to waking up early for long hike the next day.

Day 2

The trek from La Pastora to Laguna Otún is 13km (8 miles) and goes from an elevation of 2000m to 3900m (6500ft to 12800ft). It is not an easy hike, and for an experienced, fast hiker such as myself it requires pretty much the entire day.

This hike is the definition of 'off the beaten path'. I only saw two people the entire day hiking on the trail and was hiking alone through the Colombian mountains. The sense of freedom was overwhelming.

Luckily there wasn’t too much rain on this day and the path was much drier than the previous day. However, the rocky terrain continued for 8km from La Pastora to a place called El Bosque. That meant that I was still needing to rock hop, which made the hike more difficult but quite exciting and rewarding!

There were patches of forest, meadows, and many farm animals such as horses, cows, pigs, and sheep. I passed some incredible places while making the climb.

Sheep on a finca near La Secreta

Eventually, I got lost. The best trails are the ones that you make with your own two feet. Getting lost while hiking is one of the most exhilarating things for me, and having to find your way back on track.

I ended up at a place called La Secreta and then realized that something was not correct when the path ended at a gate to private property. Luckily there were people at that finca and they were super friendly (like 95% of Colombians) and showed me the way to El Bosque.

The bad news (or good news) was that they pointed straight up a large mountain and said I needed to go there! The even worse news (or even better?) was that I needed to cross a river to get to where they pointed me to.

Eventually I found a few trees that formed a small bridge and was able to successfully cross the river. Then for about 20 minutes I was scaling the side of a grassy mountain making my way up to what I hoped was El Bosque. Unfortunately after I reached the top I was still lost and there was no sign of any place called El Bosque. But it’s hard to be upset with such amazing views.

View near the top of the mountain

I made my way under a few barbed wire fences through some ranches and eventually saw a house. I made my way over towards the house and intended to ask for directions, but the house turned out to be on the main path, and I continued along until I reached a sign that said El Bosque. The funny thing is that bosque means forest, and it was actually in a meadow!

Continuing along the path I found someone else on the trail. He was a Colombian campesino (farmer) standing next to his horse waiting next to a sign pointing in the direction of la Laguna Otún. He told me there was only about an hour left to the lake, but I was skeptical.

After getting lost, I was about an hour behind schedule and was thinking about not going all the way to the lake. However, when the campesino told me there was only an hour left, my motivation to reach the lake increased.

At this point, I was getting exhausted. The climb up was challenging, and having to scale the side of the grassy mountain did not help. I needed to stop a few times to take a rest and eat some trail mix and drink water - something I very rarely do while hiking solo.

Eventually I made it high enough to where the entire ambiance changed and it was clear I was in a high andean climate. Things became drier, and the greens turned into browns. The types of plants and trees changed to something that seemed from a different planet.

Strange looking trees

After about an hour of hiking after talking to the campesino, I knew I was close. However, the clouds began to roll in, and everything became difficult to see. The paths started to multiply and there were no signs pointing me in the direction of the lake. I tried a few different paths but none of them seemed to be correct.

Fog slowly taking over my vision
Is this the right way??

There were some very strange looking plants called freilejons, and they indicated that the lake was very close. I knew I close, but could not find the damn lake!

Freilejones

After trying a few paths, I had a decision to make. I was tired, out of water, and it was later than I wanted it to be. There was absolutely no way I could be hiking in the dark so I couldn’t waste too much more time.

The fog became very thick while I was wandering trying to find the lake. If I found the lake, the pictures would be terrible anyway. I decided it was best to head back to La Pastora. I ended up not finding the lake, but overall the hike was completely successful.

The journey back was fairly uneventful with the highlight being able to backtrack on the correct path and seeing where I took the wrong path.

Where I took the wrong turn

I went right, and I should have gone left. This picture doesn’t tell the whole story - before this was a dirt path and the dirt path clearly continued on the right, but I needed to take the right path on the left. Also, cows were staring at me on the right so it was mostly their fault.

The next time find yourself near Pereira and have interest in the Quimbaya Otún area, let me know if you have any questions!
fields.headline: If you are looking for something off the beaten path, have I got a treat for you
fields.title: Hike to Laguna Otun
fields.img_alt: View over Quimbaya Otun near Laguna Otun
fields.img_title: View over Quimbaya Otun near Laguna Otun

fields.body:
My life has definitely been changing in the last couple weeks since Travel Blog Source (TBS from here on out) has gone live. I’ve been living in Kolibri Hostel in Pereira (which I highly recommend) for the last couple weeks and I’ve turned from a traveler to someone juggling many projects while traveling on the road.

Slew of projects

To be honest, I’m loving it. Today I had the first travel blogs register on TBS and I have been completely giddy all day after I saw the two new blog sites for approval in my notifications.

Other than TBS, I’ve also been developing another site to showcase my works and also act as a home for clients to interact with. I’ve already met two potential clients while traveling, and there are some other prospects in the new future.

Last but not least, I still have this travel blog which you all know and love (I hope!). I’m doing what I do best - staying busy and accomplishing a lot more than one should be able to accomplish.

Living a different life from my traveling peers

However, lately I’ve been having some unique feelings. Unique, but very positive.

After living in Hostal Kolibri for an extended amount of time, it feels “strange” being so different from other travelers.

It’s strange sitting in the hostel working in the day while the other people look at me curiously while I slave away on my computer all day after declining invites to go to sites that I have already been to.

New travelers arrive every day, we build a short-lived friendship, and then they leave after two or three days. The same questions get asked over and over again - Where are you from? How long have you been traveling? How long have you been in Colombia? What have you liked the most? With some people a stronger friendship is formed, and with some it’s just a temporary friendship that will fade as soon as they head to their next destination.

Even though it’s not as much of a shock to other travelers as to people back home when I say “I’m traveling for 1-5 years, I think”, it still is something different for travelers. When people find out about my projects that I work on they become intrigued. The majority of my clients will be people I meet on the road.

If you think about it, it’s almost perfect. I get to tell people about my TBS site, whose clients are mainly travelers and people with travel blogs. I will be meeting many of those people during my travels.

I also have a chance to talk to many people about custom development, which some people on the road have a need for (I’ve already met 2 in just a month). In a fixed location, I would never be able to talk to so many diverse people, nor find as many clients.

If you liked this post, please consider sharing! Follow @stepsoftravel Tweet'

It feels great to be travelling while also having projects and income streams in the near future. It makes it even better that some of the income streams are in something I greatly enjoy - web development. I believe I have now made the transition from a traveler to a working traveler. Now I just need to start making money! It will come.

Why work while traveling?

Some people wonder why I would want to work when I am in these beautiful foreign lands traveling. Well, the truth is that I could be working in a fixed location, or I could be working all over the world for an undetermined length of time.

Seems like a simple decision to me? It’s a different lifestyle - definitely life out of the box.

Some days I take a break and do the touristy things. Some days I go out with friends from all over the world I meet while traveling. Some days I take a day trip to a nearby pueblo. Some days I just have a normal day working. It’s amazing, and I’m loving it.

The flexibility and spontaneity of this life is something unmatched. Running two websites while also working on other people’s projects while on the road presents many obstacles and challenges, but it provides something to learn and improve each and every day.

Related Post: The Game of Life

Related Post: What is Long Term Travel?

As discussed previously, I was thinking about settling down in Colombia. I was very seriously considering it. However, with these projects I’m now at such an advantage to work while traveling that I need to pursue it. I know I will miss beloved Colombia, but if it’s really that bad I could always return early.

How awesome would that be if everything turned out and I could just travel to my heart’s will while earning more money than I spend? Been working on this dream for a while now, it feels completely surreal to finally see it begin to blossom.
fields.headline: My life has definitely been changing in the last couple weeks since Travel Blog Source went live
fields.title: Life as a Working Traveler
fields.img_alt: Traveling While Working

fields.body:
Hidden away up in the mountainous coffee triangle region of Colombia, Salento offers a tranquil, peaceful experience. There is a certain feel about Salento that just takes all the stress away from daily life and opens up the mind.

There is one main street which is lined with stores and restaurants which starts in the central plaza and ends atop of a lookout point. Salento is quite a small pueblo, which greatly adds to its gentle ambiance.

View overlooking Salento

At the end of the main road, there is a long flight of stairs that leads to the mirador overlooking the city. After getting to the top there were some locals on the playground and only a couple tourists to be seen. The view over Salento was decent, but it would soon be overshadowed by the breathtaking views of Valle de Cocora, which I would go to the next day.

I had arrived a little late to Salento, so after climbing the mirador and exploring the stores in the street for a bit, I headed back to the hostel - La Casa de Lili. With a mountain feel and a quirky, friendly owner, the hostel turned out to be one of my favorites I have ever visited.

The next day I woke up early with some of the other people of the hostel and we headed out to the central plaza to catch a jeep out to the trailhead for the valley hike. Half asleep, a Costa Rican, a French, a Czechoslovakian, a Dutch and myself made our way through the Colombian countryside towards the trailhead.

The sun was still rising, and the shadows were fading across the valley. We made our way through the muddy trails, across the breathtaking terrain.

Making our way through the muddy terrain

After a few kilometers, the terrain changed from an open valley to a dense jungle. The hike was actually one of the more interesting hikes I’ve done because of the wide diversity. We continued along through the jungle, which had some similarities to Rio Claro.

The winding path continued for another couple kilometers weaving across about 5 or 6 questionable rickety bridges. Mother nature decided to scare us a bit by offering some sudden rain and wind, but it faded by the time we started making the ascent up to a place called “The Mountain”.

One of many bridges crossing the river

As we climbed out of the jungle, the path became steep and the pace of the group slowed down. This phase was definitely the most difficult of the hike, but absolutely nothing in comparison to hikes through the Wallowas, Mt. Adams, or other hikes in the ol’ USA.

Eventually we got to the top of the trail and arrived at The Mountain, where we found out that we weren’t actually climbing a mountain, but it was a place that had a great view of a mountain across the valley.

View of the The Mountain across the Valle de Cocora

We took an extended break at The Mountain and sat down on the benches while eating a few snacks and conversing about various topics that a group of travelers usually talk about.

When we arrived at the top, there were not many clouds, however the clouds began flooding in up the valley at an incredible pace. Watching the clouds rush in through the narrow valley door and rise up to our level was something interesting to see, however at the same time it was concerning because some of the best views were still to come. Had we waited too long at The Mountain?

We started the descent down, which was much easier than the climb up, obviously. For a while, it wasn’t too impressive. We weren’t walking on a trail, but a road. At one point, we came up to a gate which was locked, which made us question whether or not we missed a path we were supposed to take.

However, soon after the gate we found out we were headed in the right direction with the best view yet of the valley. We took another long break and took in the memorable view while discussing in depth the World Cup.

View overlooking Valle de Cocora

After a while, even though we would have loved to stay there all day, we decided to continue so that we could go to a coffee tour after getting back into town. Continuing our descent down the dirt road, we eventually made it to a clearing. Wow. Stunning.

Stunning views through the Valle de Cocora

We definitely saved the best for last, making our way through the curvy dirt road through the Valle de Cocora with countless of the famous Wax Palms towering above us on all sides. I took so many pictures and had to tell myself, “Ok. Stop. These are all the same!” But the views continued to be amazing all the way back down while we walked along the dirt road and grass fields to arrive back at the trailhead to catch a jeep back to Salento. For more pictures check out my Coffee Triangle Album.

After getting back to Salento, we had plans to go to a coffee tour outside of town, but a downpour of rain quickly crushed those plans. We had some luck because the jeep driver was nice enough to drive us to a restaurant to eat lunch instead of leaving us at the central plaza where we would normally get out.

The rest of the day was mostly spent inside due to the weather, and the next day I would head to the coffee tour at the Finca de Don Elias.

After waking up and eating a delicious Colombian breakfast in the hostel, I made my way through town asking locals how to get to the finca of Don Elias. Luckily, one person knew what I was talking about and was able to point me in the right direction. I had to ask about 6 other people before someone was able to confirm I was in fact walking the right way.

There is something special about walking through the colombian countryside solo. There is a sense of freedom and solidarity which frees the mind. It’s a similar feeling to backpacking through mountains. Peace and serenity squelch all problems.

Stunning views all the way to the finca

After about 3 kilometers, finally I arrived to the coffee finca. A few little girls (about 3-4 years old) met me at the gate and told me to come with them to their grandparents house. They led me down the path through some banana trees and soon enough we got to the finca where I met their cousin, and he would be my tour guide.

He was a 20 year old Colombian and was super friendly. When he was not telling me about the coffee farm, we talked about my love for Colombia. What an interesting life they have there on the finca - it made me wonder if some day I would have a Colombian finca in the country.

He was way more friendly than he looks in this picture!

After the tour, I bought a bag of their fresh coffee for a regalito and made my way back towards Salento where I would meet up with my Costa Rican friend to head to the nearby city of Pereira.

I highly recommend going to Salento if you visit Colombia, it is very high on my list of things to see in Colombia. I’ll be making that list in a few weeks when I finally leave my beloved Colombia and make my way into Ecuador.
fields.headline: Don't pass up the tranquil, peaceful experience of Salento Colombia
fields.title: Salento and Valle de Cocora
fields.img_alt: Colombia Valle de Cocora mountains nature
fields.img_title: Looking over the Valle de Cocora near Salento

fields.body:
Well, It is November 29th which means today marks my 3 month anniversary in my beloved Colombia. So many thoughts have been going through my head during my time in Manizales, and I have no idea how I’m supposed to contain them all to fit in one focused post. But, I will try my best.

I definitely accomplished my main goal for my time in Colombia, and that was to decide if and where I wanted to move to in the future. After living up to its high expectations, Medellin quickly stole my heart away from Bogota. For some details, I would suggest reading my First Impressions of Medellin.

I had 2 goals for things that I did not want to do.

The first thing was that I didn’t want to get involved with work. Fail... Fail. I totally failed, hard. The last 2 months I have been completely engulfing myself in my Travel Blog Source project. The good side is that after 2 months of website development and business planning, I’m days away from opening it up to people who are wanting to poke around and test.

On top of that, while writing this article a guy that I’m living with approached me about building a website for him. He just bought a house here in Manizales and is going to start a Bed and Breakfast. Now I’m thinking about expanding the scope of my business to do freelance web development and Travel Blog Source would essentially be one of my customers (along with this blog!). Oh the options…

I mean, come on, let’s be realistic. I’m such a dedicated and motivated person and after about two weeks in Medellin I had the itch to do something special. I wasn’t traveling, I wasn’t studying, and I wasn’t working. I needed to do something! To be honest, I’m not too disappointed, and I kind of knew I was going to fail.

The second thing that I wasn’t supposed to do was get emotionally attached to a lady friend and lead myself to abandon my trip. I was particularly scared about failing this one, but I would say this one was a draw.

I definitely have become very emotionally attached to someone in particular, but we’ve known the situation the whole time. It’s been hard, but I think we’ve done enough so far to squelch our feelings/relationship and I do not have plans to cancel my trip because of her. But, it has not been easy. Shoutout to my paisa, my hidden-one, my guide, my little ugly-one, and my giraffe. Obviously some things are just better off left in spanish… I leave it at that.

Should I stay, or should I go?

But wait a minute, let’s think about why I made these goals in the first place. Here’s a hint, it all hinges around my decision to stay in Colombia or travel Latin America.

The details are in the article, but I knew coming into this that it would be hard to leave Colombia. The reason I had these goals of things not to do were because these are things that would keep me in Colombia.

But Adam, if you love Colombia so much, why are you leaving?

Funny you should ask me that, I’ve been asking myself the same damn question!!

Here’s my rationale - I know if I stay in Colombia right now, there’s a good chance I will stay here for a while. There’s also a good chance I’ll meet someone, and I want to start a family in the next few years. Yes mom, you read that correctly, and no, you don’t need to publicly comment on it.

In the present time, I really want to just get an apartment, get a job, and stay in Colombia until a day comes when I decide it’s time to move on.

However, the future always gets in my way. Will I ever get the chance to freely travel again? Maybe. It would become increasingly more difficult over time with decreased earnings and possibly picking up a travel companion.

My time in Manizales has given me time to reflect, what do I really want? Being away from Medellin has made me understand what a fantastic city it is, but unfortunately, I still don’t quite have the answer.

Problems of solo traveling

Back in the day when I was constantly answering questions about my trip, people would ask me, “Are you going with anyone?” Well, as you can imagine, the answer was always no. Unless I felt like being snide and sarcastic, then maybe I answered a bit differently.

Solo traveling has a unique dynamic, something that many people don’t have a full grasp upon. For long-term travel (which essentially means making travel your life for years), it’s quite difficult to include anyone else. A significant other is usually the only exception.

The flexibility is addicting. The freedom is inspiring. However, sometimes the uncertainty and loneliness can be wrenching. Especially for someone a bit introverted like me who does not have the easiest time meeting new people.

Closing thoughts after 3 months

These months in Colombia have cemented my thoughts that Colombia truly is a beautiful country. The landscape, the people, the culture, and the general vibe captivate me. Right now, the opportunity in Colombia is limited, but the country is improving every year.

In this final month, the big question will be should I stay, or should I go? Should I go with my brain and continue along my path, or should I go with my heart and stay in Colombia? During the next few weeks in Manizales, Salento, Armenia, and the rest of the coffee triangle I will have plenty of time and solitude to think things over.
fields.headline: Well, It is November 29th which means today marks my 3 month anniversary in my beloved Colombia.
fields.title: After 3 Months in Colombia
fields.img_alt: Colombia Collage

fields.body:
San Andres could very well be the most photogenic place in Colombia. You can’t find comparable caribbean beaches anywhere else in Colombia except for possibly the islands of Baru. Providencia would be another place, but that’s right next to San Andres so for the sake of argument I’m grouping them together.

To be honest, I had not been planning on going to San Andres. I’m now a budget traveler, and it’s quite out of the way for something that doesn’t satisfy my travel style

One of my friends I met in Medellin from Couchsurfing found some cheap tickets and decided to head out to the island paradise. I had to take a look at the prices. To my surprise, a round-trip ticket from Medellin to San Andres was only $95 - final price from Viva Colombia!

With that price, I didn’t have an option. It would be idiotic not to take advantage of this low-season price. Note: in high season prices soar above $300

Getting to San Andres

After taking an hour-long bus ride from Medellin to the airport, a 3 hour delay, and a 2 hour flight, I finally arrived to the island of San Andres.

View of San Andres from the airplane

The line to check the tourism card took about 15 minutes to clear, and then it was time to find my hostel. All I knew was the name of the hostel, so I just walked the streets asking locals how to get to “El Viajero” and eventually found it on one of the main streets. Of course I could have taken a taxi, but where’s the fun in that?

The amount of locals in San Andres was different than I had expected. I was expecting more tourists and less locals - but as it turned out, about 95% of the people were locals. Not only just in the non-touristy areas, but even in the touristy areas the locals flooded the streets.

That was a good thing. I’m not at all a fan of touristy places in this phase of my life and travels. When I am traveling with a girlfriend/wife and/or family, I’m all for the touristy spots. But for now, I’m in search of real culture.

San Andres was a bit of a mix of real vs touristy. While traversing the island by bus, we passed through the real areas where the locals lived. That part was interesting. I would have liked to get out of the bus and walk around, but never took the opportunity.

In case you’re not aware, there has been a dispute whether San Andres and Providencia belong to Colombia or Nicaragua. In 2012 there was a court ruling that the islands belong to Nicaragua, but Colombia somehow “rejected” the decision and the islands are still Colombian. Anyway, what I want to say is that the neighborhoods where the locals live strongly resemble the barrios that I have been to in Nicaragua and not so much Colombia. I found that quite interesting.

The Beaches

First of all, I’ve never been to more beautiful beaches in my life. I will consider myself lucky if I’m able to find such pristine beaches and water so perfect again in my life. The beach on a small island called Johnny Cay off the coast of the main island was the best beach I encountered in San Andres.

The beach of Johnny Cay off the coast of San Andres

That beach was well groomed for tourism, but walking around the small cay (which took all of 10 minutes) led to some other great views of how the cay looks naturally.

View of the dock in Johnny Cay
Middle of Johnny Cay
Johnny Cay from the boat

After spending about 4 hours out on the cay, hunger began to set in. There were plenty of things to eat and drink on the cay, but at very high touristic prices. We decided to head over to the dock and catch the boat back to the main island.

Walk to Roquiqui

My argentinian friend I met on the island and I decided to walk to a beach called San Luis. However, after about an hour of walking, we found out that San Luis was actually quite far. He took a bike ride a few days prior and seemed to think it was closer, but it was a good adventure nonetheless!

We ended up at another beach called Roquiqui which has a shallow strip of ocean that allows you to walk through the waist-high water to another small cay.

We unexpectedly ran into some of our friends from the hostel at Roquiqui and spent the rest of the day at the beach after making the walk out to the cay.

Bike Excursion

Another highlight would have been the bike ride around the island. I decided to do the bike tour the last day, which turned out to be a mistake. But, mistakes always turn into great memories!

Making my way around the island. I was telling the person to take the picture from another angle, but I liked this pic!

From the first minute I was on that bike, I knew something was not right. The pedal kept “catching” and when I pedaled I would lose the friction for about a second. As time went on, it became worse and worse. After about half an hour it became so bad that I stopped to ask some locals if they had a screwdriver. No luck. I kept pedaling along, struggling quite a bit.

Eventually, the pedal fell off. Literally.

I had a good laugh, picked up the pedal, and began walking down the beautiful road and arrived to the San Luis beach.

After walking along the beach for a bit, I decided to hitchhike back to town to return the broken bike. About 4 trucks passed me up before I abandoned that idea, as well as the bike. I locked it up against a post and would tell the person that the bike she gave me sucks, it’s safe in San Luis, and that I needed a refund. It was about $7 for 6 hours, and she decided to give me $2 back. No big deal :)

Walking along San Luis

Lasting Impressions of San Andres

Overall, the trip was well worth it. For the price I paid, it was well worth it. The food and drinks were not quite as expensive as I was thinking either, so that was an added plus.

I really enjoyed the beaches and the ocean - they were close to perfect. For a place like this, it would have been nice to have someone special with me, but even as a solo traveler (I did go with my friend from Mexico and her german friend from Medellin) it was well worth it. I met many people there, and we all had a good time.

The thing that I didn’t like is that it was very commercialized. Everything costed money and it felt unauthentic. Good luck finding an island paradise that isn’t like that, right? Let me know if you find it.

Also, I’ve never been a fan of the coastal people of Colombia. They have a certain demeanor that is not friendly. I experienced that all along the northern coast of Colombia and San Andres was no different. I had read in another blog something like “when you go to stores, it feels like the locals don’t want to serve you”. I felt exactly that way.
fields.headline: San Andres could very well be the most photogenic place in Colombia
fields.title: Island Paradise of San Andres
fields.img_alt: Island Paradse of San Andres Colombia
fields.img_title: Island Paradse of San Andres Colombia

fields.body:
Many people have been asking me, what is this “project” you have been working on? And by many, I mean my mom and my sister. Well, I’m now at a point where I can share the idea.

Travel Blogging Industry Background

Before explaining what Travel Blog Source is, it’s necessary to gain an understanding of the basics of the travel blogging industry.

Many long-term travelers are searching for location-independent income. They search for a way to sustain travel through income revenue that does not tie them to one location. Sounds great right? Well, it’s not so easy.

One of my main goals has been to find a location-independent job. And believe me, there have been countless ideas run through my head. However, this one I actually think could work.

Travel blogs often develop over years. Owners of travel blogs start out with small vision, and then as their blog grows, they gain hundreds or thousands of followers. Having this amount of followers opens up many opportunities, which I outlined some options near the bottom of The Game of Life. Travel blogs don’t usually generate income, but when you have an audience, you have a loyal market.

Ok, so what is Travel Blog Source?

I will start off by explaining from the “Blog Search” perspective, which is the main concept of the website.

Travel Blog Source is a place for people to search travel blogs around the world. It will allow people to search by country, continent, or language. The goal is to have an up-to-date, comprehensive list of travel blogs, along with some basic info and ratings.

It will be possible to order by rating (based on user reviews) to get the highest rating blogs in a region, or you could sort on registration date to see the newest blogs.

Right now if someone wants to search travel blogs in a certain country, they turn to their trusty friend, Mr. Google. They will find 2-3 blogs which typically have been existent for at least 2 years - enough time to gain SEO power. It is almost impossible to find smaller and/or newer travel blogs. Travel Blog Source is going to change that, it is going to give the smaller blogs a chance.

Now, from the perspective of the ”Travel Blog Owner”, which just happens to be the main customer.

As stated in the background of the Travel Blog Industry, blog owners want to grow traffic. The good news is that registering your site on Travel Blog Source is completely free and takes all of 5 minutes. The blog will get a backlink (which is very important with SEO) and gain exposure to new customers. There is nothing to lose for blog owners.

It’s a pretty simple concept, but is something that is currently missing from the market.

Ok, but like, are you going to make $$?

Let me explain Sponsorships. There will be methods to increase traffic and exposure to certain travel blog sites. In the beginning, the majority of these sponsorships will be given out by social media competitions, which will not generate revenue but instead will focused on growing the user-base and traffic to Travel Blog Source.

After about 6 months (my best semi-educated guess), sponsorships will begin to shift to a pay method where blog owners can pay a small amount to either highlight their blog site in searches, or appear at the top of regional searches. There will also be other opportunities such as writing a blog post which will appear on Travel Blog Source or submitting a cover picture which will show at the top of region pages and will have a link to your blog site.

Is it almost ready?

Yes, I think so. I plan to start marketing to blog owners in December or early January.

Warning - the rest of this section might be a bit technical/dry if you’re not interested in development or business.

I’ve split the project up into 3 major groups. Phase 1 website development, Phase 2 website development, and Business Development.

Phase 1 development has been completed and that consisted of the basic design of the website and getting all the functionality in place. Right now it is possible to create a user, register a blog site, search registered blog sites by country or continent, submit feedback, rate blog sites, submit a blog post or cover image, and probably some other things that I’m forgetting.

I’m about to start Phase 2 development, which is getting all the other development stuff in place and fine-tuning the website. Things such as proper error handling, making sure everything looks perfect, testing, and implementing business process enhancements. This phase has some dependencies on the Business Development.

Business Development is the whole business side of the project. Things such as the initial business plan, marketing plan, operations analysis, financial analysis, and again some things that I’m forgetting. Some specific examples of this would be how am I going to promote the website when it’s first starting out? What business processes do I foresee in the future and how can I improve them now? What pricing model do I want to go with the services provided by TBS? My favorite is improving the business processes, most of the other stuff I just BS my way through :)

Personal Note, from yours truly

I can’t begin to express how much I’ve enjoyed developing this idea. It’s interesting being both the business owner and the developer, but that is my specialty and my strengths cater to this project. From the first day I thought of this idea I became very dedicated to it.

No matter which way this project goes, I have learned so much. Right now, most of the learning has been with the web development platform I use, but in the near future I will be learning many things about business as well. I need the challenge.

Luckily, I am able to do everything, so there are very little startup costs involved. Depending on how the first months of the project go, many different variables will come into play and I’ll need to adjust. I look forward to that phase of the business!

Depending on how this project goes will affect my long-term plans. If this does turn out to be a sustainable idea, I could be traveling for years. If I totally fail with the project, I’ll probably end up settling somewhere after year 1 and getting a real job. But, only time will tell!
fields.headline: One of my main goals has been to find a location-independent job. This one could actually work.
fields.title: My Project, Travel Blog Source
