fields.body:
It's not every day that I hear of a place in Colombia to visit that I've never heard of. After all, I've been reading extensively about Colombia for over 2 years now.

During the first couple weekends in Medellín, I asked my good friend Xiomi if there were any places she would like to visit that she hasn't gone to before. She replied without hesitation - Rio Claro.

While finding my travel style, I found that I enjoy spending time with locals rather than other travelers. One thing that I do find even better is exploring new places with a local. Their excitement of venturing to a new place directly transpires to my mood which enhances the experience for all.

We found a 3-day weekend when we were both available, and picked those dates to head to Rio Claro, which is about 3 hours outside of Medellin by bus.

Day 1

The drive to Rio Claro was stunning. Through the rolling antioqueñan hills, we eventually made it through the windy mountain roads to the entrance of Rio Claro.

Nature on the way to Rio Claro
The entrance to Rio Claro Nature Preserve

We made our way past the park entrance and began to scope out a camping spot. From what we read, there was “abundant space” and reservations were not needed. Luckily, that was true. There was a huge field with tents scattered about - definitely obliging to their claim of abundant space.

We found a spot nestled in a corner sitting against the river. Besides a handful of backpacking spots, I can't think of a better camping spot I've been in.

Our campsite situated next to the river

After setting up camp and eating our “gourmet” lunch consisting of nutella and jelly sandwiches, chips, almonds, and other dry foods, it was about 2 in the afternoon and time to explore the park.

We made our way through the jungle along a dirt road until we found an interesting tree overhanging the vibrant green river. Xiomi instantly got super excited and we made our way down towards the tree.

Interesting tree hanging over the river

After climbing around the tree and taking in the view for about 30 minutes, it was time to continue along the dirt path.

Stairs leading to some secret place?

We approached a makeshift parking lot with a few motos and cars parked along the side. After the parking lot came a jungle lodge for people to stay as well as the place to sign up for the rafting, climbing/canopy, or cave adventure. After some debate, we decided to sign up for the rafting and cave adventure for the following day. Lounging by the clear water, we watched a group of rafters embark upon their journey before we continued along the path.

At this point, it was no longer a dirt path. It was an elegantly made path through the jungle and we were awestruck. What an amazing place! Xiomi, along with many paisas, hadn't made the journey over to Rio Claro, and it didn't take long for us to question why not.

It truly felt like a jungle adventure, with the brilliant green river, exotic plants and trees, alluring sounds, and rock formations and caves that you wouldn't think were possible.

Trail Pic!

We approached a few cliff jumps which were 8m and approximately 10m. I don't really enjoy being wet when I have to do things after or there is some uncertainty, so I didn't make the jump on this day. Xiomi, on the other hand, was all for it.

She waited for the other people to pass so she could shed some clothes and jump off the 8m plank. I descended down the path to meet her at the shore and her demeanor had completely changed. The excitement that filled her face was priceless and her new mood instantly improved mine… as if it needed to be improved in the first place. To be honest, she seemed a little too excited so I asked her if she'd ever jumped off a cliff before. No. I then understood why she was so utterly happy :)

View of the cliffs from around the bend. Can you spot them?

We continued along the path, which by the way was not crowded at all on this day. Throughout the whole path we continued to be impressed, it wasn't just a small stretch. We were simply stunned by the raw beauty of the natural jungle. Much talk ensued about never returning to Medellin and living in a jungle tree. As you can see, unfortunately, that didn't happen. Yet.

We arrived at a “beach” which was a large rock area that formed a bend in the river. We stopped for a few pictures and to take in the view before continuing on. There was another beach, Cave of Guacharos, Door to Paradise and Boca Caiman still to see, and daylight was running out.

Xiomi sitting by Rio Claro

It didn't take much time to arrive to the next beach and the cave, which were situated across the river from each other. As with the rest of the park, there was not much overcrowding which enhanced the tranquility and authenticity of the whole experience.

We decided this was the best swimming place, and we would stop here on the way back, or in the next day to do some swimming. Onward to the end.

We continued walking along the path focused on finding the door to paradise. We thought we had already arrived to paradise a long time ago, but oh well!

Eventually the man-made path ended and we arrived to a dirt path made in the jungle. We traversed this terrain for probably about 30 minutes while discussion of where the door to paradise and Boca Caiman were, as well as discussing when to head back. We decided to keep exploring along this jungle path until 4:30pm and then we would head back to arrive to the campsite around nightfall.

We kept going, but didn't find the door to paradise before it was time to start backtracking. We found a jungle vine, and I decided to do my best tarzan impression. The first jump surprised me, I was not expecting to go so quickly, or as far.

Doing my best Tarzan impression

We continued our trek over the dirt path and hopping from rock to rock, until we came upon a small opening in a rock.

Wait a minute, that's the door to paradise!! We had gone through this hole on the way forward, but didn't realized it.

Puerta a Paraiso in Rio Claro

We made the journey back on the same path which we arrived on, and made it back to our tent. There was still a little bit of light left, and we decided to take a swim in the river nearby the campsite. The current was really strong by our camp, but there was a line that went across which we could hold onto. After playing in the water for a bit, we retired back to our campsite, ate some dinner and then more-or-less called it a night.

I wish I could say we slept well that night, but it was quite the opposite.

The tent I bought was purchased for 45.000, or roughly $24. It did not come with a rainfly, and did not do a very good job of keeping water out. It rained. In the tent.

The sides of the tent were completely soaked, all of our bags, pillows, and anything (including my hair!) that was near the side of the tent were drenched. There were drops of rain that would fall on us throughout the whole night.

However, it all leads to memories, and I've learned to appreciate the bad experiences as much as the good ones. I appreciate them almost even more than the good memories.

Day 2

We woke up on the second day after a stressful, damp night and were ready to escape the tent and get back into the jungle.

We had the cave adventure and the rafting trip planned for the day. However, we were told if it rained at night we would need to switch our cave adventure from our 9:30 departure until a time later in the afternoon due to the strong current.

It ended up being true and we needed to switch to a 1:30 departure and have our rafting trip in the morning. However, there wasn't much time in between our two activities, and I didn't have a flashlight since something happened to my phone battery and it was no longer functioning. We would have needed to return back to the campsite to get some money and then head back to the store to buy a flashlight. I don't like schedules in the first place, and this was getting compicated. So, we decided to cancel the cave adventure and just do some adventuring of our own in the afternoon after the rafting trip.

The rafting trip was well worth the time and money that was required. Unfortunately there are no pictures of this trip, but hopefully you all have a pretty good idea of what the scenery would be like. Overhanging trees, jungle river with some gentle rapids, and a rock overhang with thousands of stalagmites dripping water into the river.

Typical view of Rio Claro

We took a break on a small beach area across from the rock overhang and wandered around that area for about 20 minutes before making the final stint down to the pick-up point. There were a couple waterfalls which we submerged ourselves under. Everything on the rafting trip was an amazing experience and it is definitely a must-do if you ever find yourself in beautiful Rio Claro Natural Preserve.

We got a ride back to the park, and were dropped off near our campsite. After eating our gourmet lunch yet again, we embarked upon a relaxing afternoon of exploring, swimming, and jumping off cliffs.

The first notable place that we arrived to was the cliffs. This time I would be able to jump in, first from the 8m drop. The scenery was awesome, and I definitely had not jumped off a more photogenic cliff. Xiomi followed me off the 8m, still a bit hesitant, and questioning how she jumped the day before. However, she made it.

I wanted more. I went up the path a little bit and after a few minutes of uncertainty, I jumped off the 10m drop. WHAT A RUSH! This one felt so much better than the 8m, and I tried fervishly to convince Xiomi to jump off. I know she would have loved it, but, I was not successful.

We continued along up to the next place of interest - Cave of Guacharos. This time, we crossed the river and made it into the mouth of the cave.

Looking across the river to Cave of Guacharos

It was quite the dramatic entrance. We needed to climb up a net rope while fighting the power of the waterfall that was pouring out of the cave. We got in and it was impressive. Unfortunately, after the first curve, it was pitch black, so we didn't get to see too much. But even the first room was great, and made a part of me wish that we had an extra day to do the tour of the cave. Oh well, next time!

After spending a couple hours inside the cave, exploring around the cave, and moseying around the beach, we headed back towards our campsite.

After the cancellation of the Cave trip, we had some extra money so we were able to eat in the near-by restaurant which is at the entrance to Rio Claro.

We had yet another rain filled night, this time, the rain was quite stronger. The rain streamed in on our faces as well as completely soaking our bags, but life went on!

The next day we swam in the river in the morning for about an hour while we waiting for our belongings to kind-of dry out. We met a friendly German girl along the road who was also waiting for a bus to return to Medellin. She had been waiting for an hour and a half for a bus, and after we arrived it took all of 2 minutes. Yeah, we're good luck.

Driving through the hills of Antioquia
fields.headline: Spending the long weekend in Rio Claro Nature Preserve
fields.title: Weekend in Rio Claro
fields.img_alt: Rio Claro Jungle River Cave
fields.img_title: Cave of Guacharos in Rio Claro Colombia

fields.body:
I’ve been wanting to visit Chicamocha Canyon for a while - it was on my short-list of places to visit in Colombia. Finally, with the wedding, I would be in Bucaramanga, which is a short drive from the canyon. The handful of Colombians that I had talked to about the canyon really talked it up. It’s stunning, it’s wonderful, it’s bigger than the Grand Canyon, and you need to go. That is what I was told from multiple Colombians. I was expecting some fantastic views, a few places to eat, and maybe a few small hikes. The diversity of the park ended up being the difference maker, and there were many attractions that I was not expecting. There were of course breathtaking views, but there was also a gondola ride across the canyon, a zip-line along the canyon ridge, , interesting statues, corral of baby goats, and of course some delicious food, and small “zoo” with many types of exotic birds, ostriches, ponies, a condor, some feisty geese protecting their eggs, and probably a few other animals that I’m forgetting about. Other than the specific attractions, the whole place in general was really well-kept, and everything was beautiful.
Walking up the path in Chichamocha
Beautiful plants all around park
I would have to say my favorite attraction was the gondola ride. While traversing the canyon, the views from the gondola were simply amazing. The ride itself took some time, I would say at least 20 minutes. The views of the canyon, rock formations, abandoned fincas, and diverse landscape were something to remember.
Ascending up the other side of the canyon
Rock formation nearing the top of the canyon
Upon arrival to the other side of the canyon, I was surprised to see it developed on that side as well. There were little shops, places to eat, and arguably the best view in all of the park.
View from the other side of the canyon
We made our way back to the main park area, and this is where the main surprise happened. I had no idea there would be so many attractions. In the back of my mind I was a little worried because I needed to take a bus back to Medellin later that night, and the bus schedule was not readily available for the route between Bucaramanga and Medellin. There was so much to see, and I was worried I might be stranded in Bucaramanga for the night. Our first stop after getting back to the main park after returning across the canyon was an area that contained little goats. I know, that doesn’t sound too exciting right? But, other than the gondola ride, the goats were my favorite part of the park. I was told they were a special breed of goat that is mainly found in Santander (the state of Colombia that we were in), and they were very cute and super friendly. On top of that, for a small fee we were able to feed the goats milk. As I was feeding the goats, I couldn’t help but think of what a great idea that was from a business perspective. The clients pay to feed the goats! If only everything were that easy.
Cabritas! Little goats!
My new friend, Mr. Cabrita
Feeding the cabrita milk
We moved on to lunch at a nearby restaurant, and I tried a local Santandereño delicacy. Ironically, it was young goat meat! For the first time in my life, I felt a little strange eating meat. Those little guys (I guess I could use the word “kids” in this case?) were so cute, and now I was eating them. But, it was some of the best meat I’ve ever eaten, so I couldn’t complain too much. After lunch, we began to ascend the well-groomed paths and stairs. I was expecting the spectacular views, but I was not expecting the special ambiance of the park, including the building styles.
Architecture of Chicamocha Park
We continued walking up the park, gaining elevation. Then, we approached a unique structure, and I’m not sure how to explain it other than showing a picture.
The interesting group of statues and structure
Yeah, unique, right? After about a 30 minute walk (it took longer because we were stopping to look at things) from the bottom, we arrived to the pinnacle of the park.
View from the top
We stopped for some ice cream, and then began descending back down the same path. However, we were not done with the attractions. Four of us decided to do the zipline, while the others split off to do their own thing for a little bit. We met back up with the rest at a small zoo. There were some exotic small birds, a condor, an ostrich, some geese, and a couple ponies which Sofi enjoyed riding around the small zoo.
Sofi riding the pony. Isn’t she cute??
Put a smile on that face, ostrich!
Not sure exactly what these are called in English or Spanish. I’ll call them pajaritos
After finishing up at the zoo, it was time to head home. Chicamocha Canyon is on the way to Bogota, so Andrea and her family continued down the road (for 7 more hours!) to Bogota, and I returned to Bucaramanga with Leonardo, Maya, and Maya’s family. After some horrendous delays due to construction, they dropped me off at the bus terminal and I made my way back to my home in Medellin after a couple hour wait for the next departing bus.
fields.headline: I’ve been wanting to visit Chicamocha Canyon for a while - it was on my shortlist of places to visit
fields.title: Chicamocha Canyon
fields.img_alt: chicamocha colombia canyon nature mountains
fields.img_title: View from the top of Chicamocha Canyon in Colombia

fields.body:
So, the arrival to Bucaramanga wasn’t the smoothest, but we made it.

After around 3 hours of sleep, we woke up and started the day. Because we didn’t need to be ready until 4pm, there wasn’t too much urgency in the morning hours.

After an interesting/delicious breakfast that I’m not sure how to explain, we moseyed around the house for a bit before Andrea, Angelica and I went to find some shoes for someone (Andrea), since that someone had forgotten her shoes in Bogota :-)

Bucaramanga is known for their shoes. They manufacture the majority of shoes in Colombia, and the area that we had gone consisted o blocks upon blocks of only shoe stores. After about 30 stores, we finally found the right shoes and took a taxi back to the house to eat lunch and get ready for the wedding.

The house was filled with about 25 family members, and 2 hours before it was time to head to the wedding, everyone was bustling around getting ready. Finally, at 4pm, it was time to go to the church for the wedding.

The ceremony was both similar and different than what I’m accustomed to. Colombia is a heavily catholic country, and the wedding was more religious than some of the more “religiousy” weddings I have been to in the states. I was not surprised at all, that was about what I had expected.

Leonardo and Maya walking down the aisle

It was a beautiful wedding ceremony, and next up was the reception, a.k.a., the fun part!

The venue was awesome! It was on a street with a bunch of walled off areas that I can best describe by comparing to mini-resort courtyards. Hopefully that makes at least a little sense? It consisted of a long, elegant pool, which was beside a large, white canopy with about 20 tables and a large dance floor in the middle. All the decor, atmosphere and ambiance were exquisite.

The Wedding Reception in Bucaramanga Colombia

Live music flowed all night, which was quite amazing and I absolutely loved all of it. It started out with some slower, romantic music while everyone was arriving and getting settled in. After the venue began to fill, the music changed to mainly salsa and merengue, which is when the dancing commenced and energy began to flow through the fiesta.

In my guayabera with Angelica. The pictures with Andrea turned out great too, but she doesn’t let me post any!

I can’t stress enough how beautiful latin dancing is. I love it. I’m addicted. I’m fairly confident I was the only extranjero (foreigner) there, so, like 98% of extranjeros I stood out like a sore thumb on the dance floor, but it’s highly acceptable, and always leads to a wonderful night :-) The important thing is that I improved a lot that night, thanks to some guided help from my friends.

We were all starving, and finally the food came. After taking about an hour break from dancing to eat dinner, the music resumed. This time, it was even more upbeat.

La hora de Locos started and that means that people put on bright-colored masks, necklaces, hats, fake ties, and probably a few other accessories that I’m forgetting. Also, other than salsa and merengue, they started mixing in some reggaeton and songs that were aimed towards group dancing. I was quite impressed with the musical agenda and performance.

After a few hours of dancing, sipping on glasses of whisky, and drinking “water” that had an identical taste of aguardiente (typical Colombian liquor that tastes like peppermint schnapps), it was time to go home. The live band played music until 2am, and then naturally, when they stopped playing, it was time to go. When that happened, I looked around and the place was mostly empty. I hadn’t realized how empty it was because our group of cousins were the main group of dancers at that late hour and I lost track of what was going on outside of the dance floor.

We gathered our belongings, figured out how everyone was getting home, and then made our way back to the house. I fell asleep within about 5 minutes, and woke up when we arrived. After getting into the house, we were exhausted and immediately went to sleep.

The next day was a fairly lazy day around the house. We explored the neighborhood for about 30 minutes, but nothing else happened until around 2pm when we went to a close pueblo called Jiron.

Walking through Jiron Colombia

We got into Jiron and stopped to eat many large plates of various types of grilled meats and potatoes. It was delicious, but I could only muster eating a few pieces because I was still sick with an intestinal problem.

View from a bridge in Jiron Colombia

After lunch, we walked through the old colonial streets of Jiron up to the central plaza on top of a hill, where we found some hormigas culonas, which is roughly translated to “big-assed ants”. These ants are famous around Bucaramanga, and so I definitely needed to try some. Surprisingly, they actually weren’t that bad! However, my chilean roommates do not share the same opinion on the quality of the hormigas culonas...

Central Plaza in Jiron
Las hormigas culonas, or ”big-assed ants”

Back down the hill through a different street, we made our way back to the cars to head back to Bucaramanga and call it a day. After all, the next day would be a long day since we would be going to the Chicamocha Canyon, which is a place that I had wanted to go since I first heard about it in the spring of 2011.
fields.headline: My first Colombian wedding, and el pueblo Jiron
fields.title: Journey to Bucaramanga (part2)
fields.img_alt: chicamocha colombia bucaramanga canyon nature naturaleza

fields.body:
After almost a month in Medellin, I took a 5-day trip over to Bogotá to meet up with my friend Mile for her graduation and then over to Bucaramanga for her brother’s wedding.

The exit from Bogotá was anything but smooth, and it was a good indication of what was to come later in the day during the journey to Bucaramanga. Bogotá has a law called “Pico y Placa” which limits the amount of cars that can drive during rush-hour. I believe it cuts down half the cars by only allowing cars with license plates that end in an even number to drive, and on the other days the license plate has to end in an odd number.

Anyway, on this day, we were not allowed to drive between 3pm and 7pm within city limits of Bogotá. We were in the center of the city for my friend’s graduation, and we ended up leaving at about 1:45, and still needed to pick up luggage at the house. There was not enough time to do that and then escape Bogotá before our time ran out.

We decided to have Roberto (the dad of the family) drive north of the city and he would wait for us there, out of the city bounds of Bogotá. We would eat lunch, head to the house to get the bags, and then take a taxi to the north of the city. Sounds like a good plan, right?

There was only one problem. We didn’t have any keys to get into the house, and Roberto had already left. To make things worse, we weren’t able to get ahold of Roberto. So, I decided to go to the north of the city via Transmilenio (bus system in Bogotá with its own lanes), find Roberto to get the keys to the house, and then head back to the house to meet up with Mile and her mom.

I love these types of adventures! Mile and her mom were stressed out and undecisive and I’m curious what would have happened if I weren’t there. To me, we only had one option, so it was a simple decision.

I went all the way to the north of the city, and then arrived to the house before Mile and her mom. They arrived and began changing their clothes (we were previously at the graduation) and packing their bags. I found out that Mile’s friend Angelica would be joining us in the trip to Bucaramanga. After Angelica (Mile’s friend) and I watched the first half of the Colombia vs Chile World Cup qualifier game, everyone was ready to head north to meet up with Roberto and finally head to Bucaramanga.

The taxi arrived, we loaded our bags, and we headed north. After finding Roberto, we loaded up into the car and began the 9 hour trek up to Bucaramanga. The graduation ended at 1:30, but we didn’t leave Bogotá until after 6pm!

The drive from Bogotá to Bucaramanga is a stunning drive. Unfortunately, we drove completely in the dark, and wouldn’t find out how beautiful the drive was until a few days later while making the drive back through the Chicamocha Canyon, which I’ll be writing about at a later time. Although, for now you can see the pictures in my Chicamocha Canyon Google+ album.

We rolled up into Bucaramanga at the bright hour of 2:30am, and then chaos ensued.

Apparently there was another family that showed up before us and were sleeping in a room that Leonardo had thought his parents would sleep in. However, the good news was that they had colchonetas (sleeping mats) set up for all of us in the main room. The parents decided it would be best to sleep in the car and didn’t want to be an inconvenience, however after a few calls from Leonardo pleading that everything was fine, they were finally convinced to go to the house and we could sleep on the colchonetas.

New problem - no one knew where he lived! We had the address, but no one had looked to see how to get there nor had any idea of where to go. This is something that I was now accustomed to with this family, it was now the norm.

We recruited the help of a questionable taxi driver who took us over to the neighborhood and we proceeded to drive around in search of the address. A few calls later, we found out we had the wrong address. All the locals who said that Carrera 39A didn’t exist were right. It didn’t exist.

It was now almost 4am, we had the correct address and were in the correct neighborhood of Bucaramanga. After meandering the streets for about 20 minutes more, we were super close to the house. We were on the correct street, but were 2 avenues away.

And then we decided to give up and sleep in the car.

What?

I was quite confused why we would have tried so hard to find the house, but then decided to give up while being so close. But, I just took it with a grain of salt and the 5 of us tried to get comfortable in the small coupe and tried to go to sleep.

I was even more confused why we would park on a main thoroughfare with noisy cars passing us at least every minute. Also, we decided to park in front of a structure that was playing loud music. It was hot. It was humid. I hadn’t eaten since lunch the previous day, 16 hours prior. I was sick with an intestinal parasite which gave me diarrhea and brutal stomachaches for the previous 3-4 days. I felt the uncomfortable sensation rise up in my gut. I began to sweat. I knew there was no chance I would be able to sleep the remaining few hours of the night, and after about 15 minutes I knew I couldn’t last any longer in the car. I felt like I was going crazy.

I’m usually all for adventures like this, but with my sickness and hunger, it just would not be possible on this night. After gathering my phone and wallet I said I needed to find a taxi and was going to sleep in a hotel or hostel.

After informing them of my departure, we decided to continue the search. They didn’t want to keep calling Leonardo because it was about 4am at this point, and his wedding was the next day. I offered to get us to the house and explained how close we were, but then they decided to call Leonardo one last time. Leonardo came out of the house to walk to the main street which we were on.

Surprise surprise, he showed up within a couple minutes on the corner 2 avenues below us. We had made it. Now everything would be great and we could go into the house and sleep on the colchonetas right? Wrong.

We parked in front of the house, but found out there were 3 large colchonetas. The girls (Mile and Angelica) offered to sleep in the car while the other 3 of us could sleep inside. The parents then decided they didn’t want to enter the house at this hour and disturb the rest of the house, and they also didn’t want to make the girls to sleep in the car. Ok… then the girls and I will go in and the parents can sleep in the car.

Nope, we then decided to drive around a bit more and search for a hotel to sleep in for the next couple hours.

I was utterly confused at this point, as was Leonardo. The logic of the past few hours made absolutely no sense to me. I love the family and they have been so great to me, but the previous few hours I just did not understand. After driving a small block, the parents came to the conclusion it would be dumb to get a hotel at this hour. Everyone agreed, and had been saying the same thing previously. We returned back to the house.

Related Post: Bucaramanga (part 2)

The girls and I entered the house, and the parents were still consistent that they were fine sleeping in the car and didn’t want to enter the house and disturb the rest of the family.

We made it. I could use the bathroom! It was 4:30am, but we had made it, finally. There was a lot of sleeping space, plenty of room for 5. Plenty of room for at least 8, to be honest. The girls shared a colchoneta, and I was sleeping on a colchoneta next to them, with more empty space than a king-sized bed on the other side of me.

What an adventure of getting to Bucaramanga. The next day was the wedding, and then we had some touristy activities planned the next couple days after that. Would those events go smoother, or would they be just as chaotic?
fields.headline: The journey to Bucaramanga would not be a smooth one.
fields.title: Journey to Bucaramanga (part1)

fields.body:
Un Techo Para mi Pais (A Roof for my Country) is an organization that I have been interested in for a couple years. Their main goal is to fight poverty throughout Latin America and improve the lives of those who are affected by social injustice and inequality.

This weekend I finally had the privilege of helping out with construction of a family in need here in Colombia, and the experience was everything I had hoped for.

We started out by meeting at 6pm at Parque de los Deseos (Park of Wishes) and after a few hours of process, instruction, and watching inspirational videos, we embarked off to our destination.

With 150 people, the logistics are always going to be tricky, but the management volunteers of Techo clearly had practiced a lot and had things well under control. There were 3 different “schools” that volunteers of Techo Medellin would stay in, and each of the schools were in different locations. People were assigned to certain buses that would go to certain schools.

The drive was not smooth. We climbed up the steep hills on the west side of the city up to the neighborhood of Santo Domingo. And then we went further. And further. We ran into a “minor” problem in Santo Domingo when another bus was stuck on a narrow bridge. After a delay of more than half an hour, we decided to try and squeeze through. I had my head poking out the window on my side, and there was less than an inch of space. Literally, less than an inch. On the other side, it looked to be something similar, but I didn’t have a good angle to see it exactly.

We finally arrived to our school, settled in, ate "dinner" at 12:30am, and then finally went to bed around 2am so that we could wake up three and a half hours later.

We might not have had much sleep, but I was full of energy and ready to start the day. We had some breakfast, gathered our stuff, and then set off to the locations to build the houses. I was one of three guys who volunteered to help unload the main truck, so we set off a little before the main group.

I didn’t know it was going to be that hard! Unloading the truck was quite tedious and consisted of moving fully-built, heavy sidings of the houses, doors, and numerous other planks. We didn’t just unload once, we had to unload so that we could get to the back t unload some stuff, and then re-load half the materials back in. And then we went to another location, and did the same thing. It was tough work, but was also enjoyable.

After we finished unloading, the rest of the crew showed up. Then it was time to carry all of the supplies up to the house locations. We’re talking steep inclines that are dirt/mud paths. This part was not simple either, but we got the job done and the six houses were ready to be started at around 11am.

View from the house

Our house had some “minor” setbacks, the first being a huge boulder that took all our strength and effort for well over an hour. We decided it was best to push it over a small ledge, even though it would most likely break the siding of the house or bathroom below. Those structures were part of the family who we were building this new Techo house for, and they encouraged us to do it. Our fear came true, and the boulder put a hole in the side of the bathroom, but we were finally successful in removing the boulder from the house site.

Huge boulder we needed to move

We then had the terrain cleared, and would spend the rest of the day putting in the large posts that the house would use as its foundation. There is quite a bit of careful measuring and leveling involved, and we were only able to get 10 of the 12 posts in before it was too dark to work. There were so many rocks which put a heavy delay on the construction.

Nighttime ensued, and the school leaders came up to inform us that we were the last group to come down, and semi-politely told us to hurry up. So, we quickly gathered our tools, and embarked down the muddy trails in pure darkness, but had a few flashlights to aid us.

We all got home, and were exhausted. What a tough day! We ate dinner, talked for a little bit, and then hit the sack.

Inside the school. It was pretty empty at this point because we were packing up.
Central plaza for the school combine we were staying in

At the bright hour of 5:30am, we awoke again to start the second day. We did the breakfast routine, packed our bags, did some stretching, and then went off to the house sites for a final day.

Well, at least that is what we hoped. Usually after the first day, you want to have the floors fully installed. We, and the other groups, were well short of that. The problem - very rocky terrain. Clearing out the ground to put in the posts was a pain, and took so long because of the rocks. Would we finish the houses in time? I was informed that this was not normal, and so I was a bit concerned.

Only a few posts left!

We ended up installing the last posts, setting the floor, and getting 3 out of the 6 walls up before 12:30, when we went to have lunch with the family. The family made some amazing traditional lunches and it was super delicious both days. What an amazing family, hearing about the life stories really makes you feel fortunate for what you have.

Not a bad view, eh?

We ate lunch quickly because we knew we were pressed for time. We headed back to the house site, and started working on the last walls. We finished the walls, set the costaneras (planks going side to side?) and then set the vigas (main planks?). After that, we began constructing the roof, with a layer of insulation, and then the metal roof. At the same time, we were also installing the door, and 2 windows.

Almost done

We ended up finishing at about 5:30pm, just in time for darkness to shroud our vision. We had a ceremonial celebration with the family for about an hour, and then headed back down.

Inside the finished house, ready for the celebration

The job was done, it was time to go home. We began the trek down to the school, again in the dark through the tough terrain.

We arrived back at the school, gathered our belongings, and then loaded onto the buses to head home. Luckily, the bus went to a metro station, and then onto the office of Techo Medellin, which is near where I live. I walked home down La Nutibara (the main street I live on) and got home to a surprised and fascinated Colombian family and Chilean roommates. I was filthy, battered, and clearly exhausted. Life goes on, and now the lives of 25 families in Medellin have been improved.
fields.headline: First Construction for families in need in Medellin Colombia

fields.body:
Jardin Botanico (Botanical Garden) was the last attraction within Medellin that I knew I needed to see. I had been to the Jardin Botanico in Bogota a couple years ago - how would the Jardin Botanico of Medellin compare to that of Bogota?

Well, there were some things that were better about Bogota, and there were some things that were better about Medellin.

The Jardin Botanico in Medellin seemed to be more family-friendly and better designed for hosting events. Although, I did go on a Sunday, so that may have been why it seemed so “family-oriented”, with many families perusing the park.

Colorful bushes lining the paths in Jardin Botanico

The other thing that stands out about the jardin botanico in Medellin is that it is free to enter. In that sense, it’s almost like a huge special park for anyone to enter. There were many vendors selling food and drinks for reasonable prices.

In the middle of the park there is a giant covered area which follows the modern architecture style of modern Medellin. On the day that I went there was some sort of dog event, and there were hundreds of dog owners inside. Unfortunately, it cost money to enter the event in the center part of the park, so we didn’t go in.

Center plaza in the Jardin Botanico, this is where events take place.

After we made a full round of the park, we went outside the park and there was much more to see. The street was filled with people, vendors, performers, and there were also other attractions all around.

Close to Jardin Botanico, there is an astronomy center, parque de los deseos (Park of Dreams), and parque explora (Explorer Park).

Real dinosaurs in Parque Explora!! I think?
Parque de Los Deseos on a Sunday afternoon

The jardin botanico in Bogota I would say had the edge of the jardin botanico here in Medellin because it was quite a bit bigger with more to see, although it did have a different feel. I liked the feel of the Medellin garden more because of the park-like atmosphere which catered to a more casual family outing rather than a tourist location.

The mariposario (house of butterflies) in Medellin was a letdown. It was tiny and I was expecting more. The mariposario in Bogota was quite amazing, and it also featured habitats with different climates such as jungle, desert, rainforest, and maybe some others that I’m forgetting.

Butterfly in the Mariposario… I think I only saw about 12

The Medellin Jardin Botanico is definitely something I would return to because it is essentially the best free park here in Medellin. The atmosphere is great, and I will definitely spend some afternoons in the park if I feel like relaxing outside.

UPDATE

I’ve now gone to the Jardin Botanico in Pereira as well, and would like to compare it to that of Medellin and Bogota.

What a difference between all 3! The Jardin Botanico in Pereira was much more natural - almost like a nature preserve. A tour guide was required and she explained to us about all the different types of plants, flowers and trees.

Walking through the Jardin Botanico

It was a few kilometers walk through a jungle-like atmosphere through a very diverse set of natural flora and fauna. We learned that in Pereira the Jardin Botanico is completely natural whereas in others many times they bring in species of plants that aren’t indigenous to that exact place.

View from a highpoint in Jardin Botanico

It’s hard to pick favorites, but I would still say the Jardin Botanico in Medellin was my favorite because of its local feel and ability to host events. However, in Pereira it feels completely different. It feels more like a hike through a forest rather than a park - and both offer unique experiences that are recommended if you find yourself in either of these cities.

fields.body:
I have a problem. It’s a serious problem. I’m always thinking ahead.

I know, I know, how is that a problem? Let me explain!

Thinking ahead isn’t always a bad thing. It’s gotten me far in life, and I’ve been able to accomplish many goals. I have so many positive things in my life, and much of it can be attributed to my long-term vision and life strategies I put on myself. I rarely just relax and take the easy road when it comes to my life.

Before this trip, I told myself that I am done living in the future and I am going to start living in the present. I quickly found out that is just not my style of living :) On the bright side, I am now happy with the present, but excited about the future. That is different than how I was living previously, when I was not happy at all with the present.

After all, how could I not be happy living in beautiful Medellin Colombia?

Building my Custom Home

One major turning point in my life was when I was building my house. I was 24 years old and having a beautiful custom home built, how incredible is that?

My house in Richland, WA, USA

It’s not just a normal home, it’s full of wonderful upgrades (a.k.a. money sinks for things that aren’t necessary) and it truly is a great home which was built exactly to my needs. Or should I say, to my wants?

One day during the construction, I couldn’t help but notice that I was thinking things like “Ok, for this home I’ll get this hardwood floor because it has the most value, but for my next home I’m going to get a better hardwood floor”. Really?! My wallet wasn’t big enough for my 100s, and my diamond shoes were too tight.

I was already subconsciously thinking about my next home, and reality struck me. Why was I in this endless cycle of wanting more and how could I escape? Why wasn’t I thinking about the home right in front of me?

Moving to Colombia

After the epiphany about my house struck me, I immediately started to re-evaluate what I was doing with my life.

It just so happened, in those times I was just starting to learn Spanish and was also falling in love with Colombia.

For the next 2 years, I was planning on living in Colombia and/or traveling throughout South America. Those were tough years to stay in my hometown, but I accomplished what I needed, and now as I hope you know, I am able to live my life and travel in my own style.

Moving up the corporate ladder

In my previous (and only) job, we had a level-based system for my job category. Employees would be level 1, level 2, etc and the best employees would eventually get up to level 5.

Anyway, during my last year I was promoted from level 1 to level 2. I had a great year, and I played my cards right to get the promotion. The interesting thing is that before I was even level 2, I was already thinking about how quickly I could get promoted to level 3.

I even took it a step further. There seemed to be quite a few level 4s, but only a couple level 5s. Because of that, my long-term vision was to get up to a level 4 quickly, and then I would be content at that level. I didn’t think too much about what I needed to get to a level 5, and to be honest, I’m not even sure if I would want to take on the extra responsibility. But, that would have been far down the road and many things would have changed by then.

The important thing to note from this example is that I look at life as a game. I love when people tell me something is impossible. I love difficult challenges, and I’m always thinking ahead.

What am I thinking about now?

Right now, and in the past year, I am contemplating ways to live a sustainable long-term travel life.

The ironic thing is that I don’t even know if that’s what I want for my life. However, I find it to be difficult goal, and the endless options occupy my mind. I solely find joy in figuring this out, and solving this problem.

Let me tell you, it’s not an easy one. Many people try to live a life of long-term travel, and very few figure out ways to make it work.

Through research, I’ve found travelers who use an array of different techniques to live a sustainable life. Some people conduct tours. Some people sell travel guide books. Some people have online technology consulting.

There are many other options as well, and I’m trying to figure out how I can fit into this world. Through the next year(s), I will be experimenting with different techniques, searching for something that is both enjoyable and sustainable.

Are my options skewed?

I woke up one morning and thought that maybe my choices are being limited.

One of the most intriguing things I learned in college was in my first year, and it has stuck with me ever since. Media is super powerful, and can change entire countries. People only know what they read and hear.

I’ve been reading travel blogs of people who generally left their home country with very little to their name but have managed to find a sustainable lifestyle. The ideas that I have read about have came from travel bloggers who have found some niche where they can sell a product or good.

However, are my options skewed? I’m different. I’m my own unique person. Do I need to limit myself into options that are generally taken by travel bloggers, or can I use my own strengths, experience, education, and creativity to find something that is a better fit for me?

If you have any ideas, please share in the comments below, I’d love to hear your thoughts!f
fields.headline: I have a problem. It’s a serious problem. I’m always thinking ahead.
fields.title: The Game of Life

fields.body:
Coming into Medellin, I had some high expectations. I had read so much about the beauty of the city and the surrounding area. I had read about how the weather was perfect day and night, almost every single day. Last but certainly not least, I had read about the abundance of beautiful paisa (people from Medellin are called paisas) women throughout the city.

After the first few days, I am now able to say with confidence that Medellin has surpassed all of those expectations.

Beautiful Medellin Colombia

I took an overnight bus from Bogotá and I woke up around 8 a.m. on top of endless rolling green mountains. We were climbing up the side of a mountain and the views from the window were breathtaking. There was no way I could fall back asleep when those views were right beside me.

We crested the ridge and then started descending into the valley in which Medellin lies. Wow. I don’t think I’ve seen a more beautiful city in my life, and I’ve seen quite a few.

One of the most amazingly beautiful things about Medellin are the streets. They are lined with all sorts of exotic trees, and just walking through the simplest of streets brings great joy.

It’s not that there were a few cool streets so I took some pics. Literally all of their streets in the Laureles neighborhood look like this or even better. It’s awesome.

The Metrocable is part of the Medellin metro which is a gondola system that scales the sides of the valley. A couple friends from the hostel and I took a ride up both of the sides of the valley, and the views did not disappoint. They did not disappoint one bit. What a beautiful city - I was shocked.

Going up the gondola on the east side of the valley
Looking down onto Medellin from the western edge

Weather, Weather, Weather

Medellin is known as the city of Eternal Spring. If you’re from where I’m from, no, this does not mean it’s March weather with high winds, ranges from 30-70 degrees and with chances of hail or snow. It’s more like May. The weather is almost always between 65 and 85 during the day and the night.

The nights are calm and around 70 degrees - perfect. Even last night it was raining and I was 100% comfortable walking in the paisa rain under an umbrella wearing only the normal jeans and T-shirt.

The days are around 80 degrees on average - perfect. This type of weather really escalates my mood and makes it tough to be cranky. I’m not sure how much else I can say about the weather, I can’t imagine better weather.

The Paisa Women

There’s quite a bit to read about the women of Medellin, and the expectations were set high. For the people who know me well, they know I have been almost solely into Colombian women (with the exception of some other latinas) for the past couple years.

I honestly didn’t think it would get any better.

But it did.

It’s a little ridiculous, and at times it doesn’t make sense. It’s astonishing the percentage of women here who are extremely attractive. I’m still trying to figure it out, but from what I know it’s just part of their culture to look a certain way and to value physical looks higher than other cultures. I’ve read that it dates back to the 1990’s when there was a lot of money flow through Medellin generated from a certain crop and the women picked up a trait of having high value in their looks to impress the higher ups. I’m not exactly sure if it actually started then or if it was a pre-existing trait here in Medellin.

Medellin is famous for its women, and it is especially known to travelers and expats. To be honest, that reputation makes me a little uncomfortable because it’s almost assumed that if you’re a single guy in your 20’s you’re going to Medellin just for the women. Because of that stereotype, I almost didn’t even want to come to Medellin. Colombia will always mean so much more to me, and I really do not want to be put into that stereotype.

But I came to Medellin, and the women truly are stunning.

If Medellin only had 2 of these 3 characteristics I feel it would still be at the top of the list of places I would want to live in Colombia. The fact that it has all 3 of these characteristics is staggering, and Medellin has surpassed all of my expectations so far.

I could live here.
fields.headline: Coming into Medellin, I had some high expectations. Would those expectations be met?
fields.title: First Impressions of Medellin

fields.body:
My 2 weeks in Bogota were very well-spent. As I have discussed before, I enjoy the simple things in travel. Some of the highlights of my time in Bogota were finally meeting Andrea and her family, working in the store of Andrea’s family, going to Tunja and Chiquinquira to meet family of Andrea, and just simply commuting around Bogota (including taking the wrong bus and ending up in a very bad part of town, don’t tell mom please!).

Andrea’s family was amazing, and they were so generous and hospitable. Having a supportive family like that is such a relief for me while I travel, and I know that I always have support when I go to Bogota.

Taking the Next Steps

As great as my stay in Bogota was, my journey will not always be like that. I will not always have tinto and juice ready for me when I wake up, nor will I have meals constantly prepared for me. I will not always have a place to call home, nor a family to support me.

The next step on my journey will be in Medellin, Colombia. In Medellin I plan to get a room in a shared apartment and live a more normal life - you know, minus the whole mandatory work schedule.

I look forward to cooking my own food, finding my own way, and thriving with more independence. It is something I’m comfortable with, and it allows me to grow more rapidly.

What will Medellin really be like?

I have been reading Colombian travel blogs for over 2 years. A couple summers ago, I became obsessed with Colombia, and the country itself became an influential part of my life. The three most memorable blogs I have read are Jasmine Wanders, Medellin Living, and Ryan Goes Abroad.

If you don’t feel like checking these blogs out, I will save you some time - all three of these travel bloggers live in the city of Medellin, Colombia. You may ask, what is it about the city that attracts these travelers?

Well, I have my ideas, and I know why these people have liked Medellin, but over the next few months I will let you know more about how I feel about the city of Medellin, as well as surrounding areas. I’m trying to keep my expectations under control. What will Medellin really be like?

It’s interesting to think about how much blogs have influenced me over the past years, and how they have shaped my life. I started out learning spanish, then I progressed to Colombia, and then I moved onto wanting a nomadic lifestyle focused in Colombia.

What do I want from Medellin?

A question that I constantly have to ask myself is what is it that I’m after. In Medellin, what do I want to accomplish? What is it that I want to do?

There are a few things that come to mind.

1. Volunteer work

Since I will be spending up to 5 months in Medellin, I will have time to settle down for some volunteer work. An organization I have been following for a while is called Un techo para mi Pais (A roof for my Country) and they work on building houses, schools, and other establishments in poverty stricken areas throughout Latin America. I am also in contact with an organizer for a program that helps children in areas with high poverty in Medellin. As you can see, my goals with my volunteer work are to help improve the poverty situation in Colombia. Ever since I started learning about Colombia, I have wanted to help out.

2. Find a simple job

I’m trying hard not to get serious and start looking for real jobs, but sometimes, believe it or not, that is one of the most difficult things for me to do. I would like to do something simple to earn a little bit of income. I would like to do something with a lot of personal interaction. The only option that I have thought seriously about is being a personal trainer, but I know other situations will pop up.

3. Figure out where I want to live

After my journey, the tentative plan is to move back to Colombia to live for an extended period of time. I don’t really like to talk about my tentative plan after the World Cup because it truly is super tentative, but I will break my rule in this post. I’ve gotten to know the Caribbean coast, Bogota and areas of Boyaca. Next up is Medellin and the coffee triangle which is south of Medellin. After these areas, I will know where I would want to set up shop in Colombia and return back to a semi-normal life.

4. Be happy

Among everything else, the main reason for this trip is to be happy. In this phase of my life, that happiness is found through living a simple life, and gaining new experiences. No matter what I do in Medellin, everything is in the pursuit of happiness.
fields.headline: As great as my stay in Bogota was, my journey will not always be like that.
fields.title: From Bogota to Medellin

fields.body:
I spent most of the weekend in the beautiful Tunja, Colombia with Andrea, her aunts and uncles, and her cousins. We worked in her family store on Saturday until about 5 p.m. so we didn’t end up getting into Tunja until around 10 p.m. after some delays from escaping the Bogotá traffic.

Tunja is a city of about 225,000 people is and is high up in the mountains of Boyacá at 9,250 feet. Upon arrival from Bogotá, you're at the top of a mountain ridge and the final destination requires going down into a valley which acts as Tunja’s floor. It’s not like typical cities which I am accustomed to where the city is based on the floor of a valley - it is actually situated on the steep hillside and extends down into the valley.

We got off the bus near the neighborhood where most of Andrea’s family lives and were quickly greeted by her cousin Lucia and her cousin’s boyfriend Pedro. After dropping off our bags, we decided to go out to dance and drink a few beers coupled with some Aguardiente. Aguardiente is the go-to hard alcohol in Colombia and the best I can explain it is that it tastes like a “minty vodka”.

Dancing in Berlin

We took a taxi and ended up at a night club/discoteca/bar named Berlin. Berlin is on the 5th floor of a building close to the center of the city, which had a stunning view overlooking the valley and the rest of the city up on the hillside.

They played a mix of Reggaeton, Salsa, Electronic, American Pop, and some older stuff that I’m not too sure how to classify.

I quickly remembered how much I enjoy latin dance. As you may have heard, latin dancing is quite different from the dancing in the states. It’s something that is quite challenging, especially since I started when I was 24 and everyone here knows how to dance to all the latin rhythms before they exit the womb.

Watching good salsa dancers is beautiful. The rhythm, the closeness, and the connection form dancing which is magical. I can almost hold my own for a gringo (at least that’s what people tell me, I think they lie though), but it is an art and each time I practice I can feel myself getting better. Someday I hope to dance like the Colombians, but I’m starting to think it is something similar to my accent in Spanish and I will never be able to completely transform.

View from the Berlin Nightclub

After finishing off the half bottle of Boyacense Aguardiente and a few beers, it was 2am and it was time to head home. We proceeded to walk down the hill towards the house while having some very interesting conversation about legends of Tunja and learning some words/phrases that aren’t supposed to be repeated.

We stopped into a restaurant called El Rey and got some food before finishing the trek back to the house. Apparently caldo (broth) is the Colombian version of Denny’s or any greasy food. It’s known here to sober you up, and also is the go-to cure for hangovers. I was feeling perfect, and decided to go with the chicken and french fries.

After adding some food to our stomachs, we finished the 2 mile walk home to Andrea’s.aunt’s house. It’s quite refreshing to walk through the fresh, clean mountain air of Tunja in the middle of the night. It also definitely is more adventurous and interesting than getting a ride home, especially when you’re in a foreign land speaking Spanish the whole time!

Exploring Tunja

I woke up around 8:30 a.m. and was ready for the day. As soon as I got up, Andrea’s aunt Etel had the customary coffee and juice ready, and then began to cut up the fresh fruit, make eggs with salchicha (more or less sausage, I think), and prepare the hot chocolate and fresh bread. This is the typical breakfast up in the Colombian mountains, and it is delicious. Also, this is the customary service, and it’s something I am definitely getting used to!

A couple of the cousins woke up and joined me for a leisurely breakfast while we waited for Andrea and another cousin to join us from the other aunt’s house which is just down the block.

After Andrea and her other cousin arrived, the 5 of us off to explore the city of Tunja. We walked through the streets of central Tunja looking through elegant churches, luscious gardens, and the entrances of historical museums. We didn’t go into the museums because they cost money to enter, and we decided there were better things to do for free.

Garden near central Tunja

We ended just before lunchtime and sat in the main plaza eating some refreshing treats that are the same as Otter Pops. After the Otter Pops were depleted, it was time to head home for lunch. We walked home again, through the same street that some of us had walked the night before.

After we arrived to Andrea’s aunt’s house, other family started to pour in. Their grandma, a few other aunts and uncles and a few more cousins joined us and we all ate a delicious lunch together.

Andrea’s family is super close, the closest family I have ever seen. It’s almost like it’s one big family instead of 4 separate families, I’m not sure how I can explain it with words. Colombian families are already close, but Andrea’s family takes it a step further.

Obviously a lot of it has to do with how the Andrea’s mom’s family was raised, but it also helps that there are about 10 cousins who are between the ages of 21 and 26, as well as 3 of the families living a few blocks away from each other in Tunja. Experiencing their family culture and customs is something that has immediately impacted me and something I will truly miss when I move further away to Medellin, Colombia later this week. They’ve accepted me into their family and everyone is so friendly and caring towards me - it is something special.

Family Fun Activities

After lunch was over, we had a tough decision to make. Should we go play Tejo or should we go play soccer? Tejo is a traditional Colombian game which involves throwing rocks onto a slanted board and trying to hit the target which has some explosive gunpowder. I’ve read about it quite a bit, but have yet to play it. As you can probably guess from the last sentence, we decided to go play football with about 10 members of the family.

Playing soccer with the family was a great experience. We ended up playing 4 on 4 which consisted of people of all skill levels, spanning a couple generations and involving guys and girls. Some of us played in jeans, running shoes, long sleeve shirts, and it was a unique and enjoyable experience.

It was obviously casual but there was also a little competitive edge at the same time. Most importantly, it involved a lot of laughing! Playing football with the family is part of their culture and is another thing I wouldn’t mind incorporating into my life in the future. Reason #348 why I love Colombia.

It felt fantastic to be running around again. One thing that I will change quickly when I move to Medellin is my workout schedule. I miss working out and exercise - besides walking around, I haven’t exercised at all for almost 2 weeks. However, let me tell you, playing soccer is quite different at 9,200+ feet versus the 300 feet to which my body is accustomed to. I ran around like normal for the first couple minutes but then after the sensation of needing to vomit presented itself, I decided to turn it down. I didn’t want to give gringo soccer a bad name!

Our team ended up victorious winning the hard-fought, defensive match which ended up 12-10 after about 40 minutes. When the match was over, we packed up our stuff and headed back across the street to our neighborhood. On the way home we ran into a friend of the family and decided to spend the evening playing a Spanish pictionary game which he had and the family enjoyed.

I’m usually terrible at pictionary, but I feel like I ended up doing better than usual. The only word I completely blanked on drawing was “Quality”. How the hell are you supposed to draw “Quality”! Luckily it was one of only a few words that none of the teams could guess correctly before the time ran out, so I didn’t feel too bad.

Playing Spanish Pictionary with the family

I would love to play the game again because I learned so many new words. Coupling new words with drawing them helps immensely for retention, and I think I remember about 80-90% of the words that I learned on that night.

Our team took a sizable lead and were only a few spaces away from winning, but another team made a comeback to steal the victory from us. Oh well, at least we won the football match!

After pictionary was done, we were all mentally drained, and decided to call it a night. For some of us, this was amplified by the fact that we had gotten home at 4 a.m. the night before which meant we only slept about 4 hours before embarking upon the beautiful day.

We headed back to the other aunt’s house, which is where we were going to sleep, and finished the night by watching some TV and a movie.

Final Day at El Mirador

At first we had planned to only stay in Tunja for 1 night, but that turned into 2 nights in order to spend a little more time with the family as well as to allow me to get a good picture of the city. I wanted to get a picture of the city from a scenic vista, so Andrea, 3 cousins, and I took a short drive up to the ridge on the other side of the valley looking down upon Tunja.

Viewpoint overlooking Tunja

It was drizzling and cloudy, so the pictures didn’t turn out as well as I would have liked, but it still gives a good idea of how Tunja is situated, and hopefully brings across some of the beauty of Tunja.

After I accomplished getting some pictures from el mirador, we headed back into town to drop Andrea and I off at the bus station to return home.

I had an amazing time in Tunja doing things I’ve never done before and gaining insights about life. I was able to reflect quite a bit about what my life is turning into and am excited for the next few months as I switch into a new phase of my journey where I become more self-sufficient and have more independent experiences.

The experience with Andrea’s aunts, uncles, and cousins was unforgettable, and I can’t wait to see them again when I go to Andrea’s brother’s wedding in October!
fields.headline: Trip to Tunja to visit with Andrea's family again as well as to explore Tunja
fields.title: Weekend in Tunja Colombia
fields.img_alt: tunja, colombia, viewpoint, vista, mountain, hills

fields.body:
It all started at the wonderful hour of 4:30am when Andrea, her parents, her sister in-law, and I woke up to embark upon a road trip through the Colombian countryside.

First of all, the Colombian countryside around Bogotá is beautiful. That is a lot for me to say since I come from a region of the United States which is rich in mountains and beautiful landscapes. The drive northeast of Bogotá to Boyacá is full of steep, lush mountains which only pictures can fully describe.

Landscape near Chiquinquira Colombia

We arrived at Andrea’s aunt’s beautiful finca (country home which usually has a large yard full of animals and plants) in Chiquinquirá. We proceeded to talk with her aunt and uncle and then of course had a delicious Colombian breakfast of eggs, bread, fruit, and hot chocolate.

Backyard patio of Andrea’s aunt’s finca
Backyard of Andrea’s aunt’s finca

About an hour after breakfast, we began to prepare lunch. However, the preparation ended up taking about 4 hours. For lunch we made a stew of chicken, potatoes, and yuca which was cooked on top of a wood fire which was sheltered under an interesting shack.

Cooking the stew containing chicken, potatoes, and yuca

After the stew was cooking on the fire, we headed to the market to pick up some fresh produce. The region we were in (Boyacá) is known for its agriculture. So, that means that the fruit and vegetables were super fresh straight from the farms.

Marketplace in Chiquinquira

We spent about a half an hour in the market and acquired a large bag (about 40 pounds I would say) of fresh produce, as well as a separate bag full of mandarin oranges. The stew was not being watched, so we heading back to the finca.

The stew took a while to cook, but time always passes very well when talking Spanish. Lunch was about ready, and then the surprise cake for my birthday came. As many people close to me know (including Andrea), I do not like my birthday. I was hoping that Andrea would forget that it was my birthday, and I thought I was in the clear.

However, they decided to surprise me with a cake, and it was really sweet of her to arrange that. In the end, I enjoyed the cake, and especially the surprise. The fact that she knew I don’t like my birthday and hid it so well was very sneaky of her, but it paid off.

Surprise birthday cake

Now, it was time for lunch. We extracted the chicken, potatoes, and yuca. Everything smelled amazing, and it tasted even better. What a great lunch!

Taking the chicken out of the stew with Andrea's dad

After lunch we went over to the main plaza of Chiquinquirá and checked out their church as well as a museum. If you aren’t aware, pretty much all cities in Latin America have a central plaza with an enormous church. I’ve seen a bunch of these churches/plazas, and I’ve definitely lost interest.

We walked back through the intriguing streets of Chiquinquirá and returned to the finca. It was getting late, and we still wanted to go to Tunja to visit with a couple other aunts of Andrea.

The drive from Chiquinquirá to Tunja was the opposite of smooth. Through the pothole laden road, we continually were bouncing up and down in our seats. I’m not going to lie, it was quite entertaining!

There’s a famous city that we drove past called Villa de Leyva. We didn’t stop there because of the time, but to show the landscape we were driving through, I’ll share a picture I took of the nearby pozos azules during my first trip to Colombia. Boyacá has some beautiful country.

Los Pozos Azules near Villa de Leyva

Through the rough country road, we finally arrived to Tunja. What a beautiful city! I’d say it’s probably the most photogenic city I’ve been to in Colombia. However, I have some bad news, and I have some good news. The bad news is that I didn’t take any pictures of Tunja. The good news is that I’m going to return on Saturday with Andrea to hang out with her family again! I definitely won’t forget to take pictures this time.

The city is down in a steep valley, and the city stretches up the hillside. It sits above 9100 feet, which is one the highest cities in Colombia. I could try to explain more about the beauty of Tunja, but it will be best to share some pictures next week.

Andrea’s family is incredible. They continued to enforce my statement that Colombians are the most friendly people in the world. They stretch the limits of being generous, kind, social, and loving. Even though I had just met them, I was informed repeatedly that I have my own room for when I come back to Tunja.

In Tunja, Andrea has 3 aunts that live all within a few blocks of each other, and I was able to meet 2 of the families, and will probably meet the last one this weekend. There are about 7 cousins that live in those 3 families, and everyone is very close to each other. Tunja was an awesome experience, and I’m very excited to return in a few days!

After starting our day at 4:30am, it was now almost 9pm in Tunja and we still needed to drive about 3 hours back into Bogotá. So, it was time to go. The ride home involved a lot of sleeping, so it went by in a blink of an eye.

We ended up getting back to la casa at about 12:30am, ending our day 20 hours after it started. What a great day! And also, what a great birthday!
fields.headline: Roadtrip through beautiful, lush landscapes to the cities of Chiquinquirá and Tunja
fields.title: Colombian Countryside Journey

fields.body:
My Style of Travel

Traveling may seem like a simple topic, but when you start exploring different options, it quickly becomes complicated. Before I began reading travel blogs and expanding my knowledge about travel, I had a mindset that travel meant going to foreign lands, checking out all the best sites I had time for, and staying in hostels and/or hotels.

This typical idea of travel satisfies the needs of people who are looking to see noteworthy sites, as well as take some stunning photos. These are the types of things that you can talk about to your friends and they will be quite impressed.

That is not my style. It can be quite costly and can also quickly become mentally draining - both which don’t work for traveling for a long time. From my experience, people naturally have this vision of travel, but are not aware of long-term travel. Long-term travel is not something that comes naturally, it is something you have to learn about.

Although brilliant photos are enjoyable and necessary in my style of travel, that is not what I enjoy the most. My main mission for traveling is to experience different cultures and different ways of life, and there are many ways to accomplish that mission.

Where to stay?

The “go-to option” for simple travel is hostels, but I quickly found out through my travels that hostels are not the best way to accomplish my mission. I have naturally formed an ordered list of accommodation preferences, and that list is in no way static. I’m always looking to learn about new options.

For me, the absolute best situation is to stay with a friend, and spend time living with their family. Right now, I’m a bit spoiled because I’m living in Bogotá, Colombia with the family of my amazing friend I met through Livemocha almost 2 years ago. Even though we never met in person, we maintained a good friendship through all this time, and now I am experiencing Colombian culture every minute of every hour of every day with her and her family.

I’m making empanadas. I’m speaking Spanish 99% of the time. I’m learning about family customs and traditions which would be impossible to experience while staying in hostels. This is my third time in Colombia, but I’ve only been here a few days during this trip and I have already learned so much.

However, this form of travel is not sustainable in the long-term. I have made a few friends in South America through Livemocha, however I will not always be able to stay with them. My next step I will be spending a few months in Medellin, and I am planning on renting a room in a shared apartment which has many of the same perks as staying with a family but is more realistic in the long-term.

After these preferred accommodation options there are a few others that I am aware of - hostels, Couchsurfing, and volunteer work that provides living. I’ve traveled quite a bit, but I have never done long-term traveling until now, so I am expecting to learn about new options or variations of the choices that I’m currently aware of.

First of all, I will do anything possible to not stay in hostels. To me, the ubiquitous English is the most painful aspect of hostels. Being around other travelers and sharing interesting stories is great, but most of the time the next day they are gone. Improving my Spanish is mandatory.

Other than not being able to immerse myself in the Spanish language, hostels don’t allow immersion in the local culture either. It doesn’t allow to grasp reality of everyday life, it just exposes a facade presented to what travelers typically see. Staying in hostels diminishes the point of why I travel, and for that I only stay in hostels if I’ve exhausted all other choices.

Couchsurfing is also a quality option, especially when only staying in places for a few days. This form of travel does lend itself to exposure in culture and language, which fulfills my main goal for traveling. Not only do you get exposure to the culture, but you also get acquainted with someone who is open to traveling and is familiar with the area. The downside for me is the length of stay. Typically anything more than 3 days is pushing the limits, and sometimes it can be tough to find a host in certain cities, especially on short-notice. If it’s not short-notice, it takes delicate planning into the future, which is a no-no for me.

During the more traditional travel phase of my journey, I will inevitably be spending some nights in hostels. If Couchsurfing doesn’t pan out in certain cities or towns, the only option left is hostels. I’ll also be looking for certain volunteer opportunities, but at this point I haven’t researched those opportunities enough to be comfortable, but I know it’s a feasible option.

Conflicts With Travel Goals

Sometimes I am conflicted on what I should do while on travel. I first ran into this problem on my short backpacking excursion through Central America.

The problem I ran into is that I enjoy the simple things more than the exciting things. I enjoy walking through the streets and looking in stores. I enjoy learning about the real culture. I enjoy riding the buses and watching the buildings and people fly by. Most of all, I simply enjoy talking with locals.

People want to see spectacular pictures. People want to hear breathtaking stories. But what do I want?

No one wants to read about how amazing walking to the store “Alkosto” a couple nights ago with Andrea and her mom was. We walked through the dimly lit back-streets over to the busy Calle 68 in northwest Bogotá. It was eye-opening to see the sidewalks crowded with people with noises flooding in from all angles generated by the traffic, hundreds of people walking and talking, and latin music blaring from the countless stores that line the streets.

This experience doesn’t produce pictures, nor interesting stories. However, I thoroughly enjoyed the walk, and it is exactly what I seek in my style of travel.

When I tell people that I’m going to Peru, the first thing they ask is if I’m going to go to Machu Picchu. My answer is that I will go there, but there are so many other amazing sites in Peru.

Machu Picchu is obviously very photogenic and recognizable. It is also filled with tourists. There are many cases where the tourism drives me away, but Machu Picchu is something that I feel the experience will outweigh the downside of not experiencing real Peru. Barely.

Machu Picchu is a necessity, and I will be going there. However, I am more excited about the simple things. I’m exciting to meet up with a couple friends in Peru and see what their lives are really like. I’m exciting to see the differences between Peru and Colombia. Being just a few days into the journey, nothing is set in stone. Maybe my priorities will change tomorrow? Maybe I’ll have the same reason for traveling in 11 months when I’m finishing up in Brazil, or maybe my reason for traveling will be completely different. Only time will tell.

If you’d like, please share in the comments below. What is your travel style? What value do you find in traveling?
fields.headline: Traveling may seem simple, but when you start exploring, the options are endless
fields.title: Finding your Travel Style
