fields.body:
After gaining enough real experience in Colombia, I fell in love with the country and every ounce of me wanted to move there and settle down. I had researched different types of visas, looked at apartments, and even applied to a few jobs.

However, I had a choice to make. Was I really ready to settle on Colombia and abandon my long-term travelling aspirations? I had dreams of living in countries for 3-6 months at a time, living a normal life, and picking up the languages and cultures.

I also had dreams of travelling through all of South America and seeing what else there was to offer while picking up different dialects of Spanish and different ways of living. After all, before going to Colombia the first time, I was expecting it to be similar to Mexico. I was very wrong. And any Colombian reading this will be upset by that statement! Were the other South American and Central American countries just as different?

Move to Colombia or Continue Exploring?

I had to decide whether to hold onto these dreams, or follow my heart and simply move to Colombia. It was not an easy decision, and something I thought about for the better part of a year. I had gone back and forth, and back again… and then forth… and the I was lost.

Moving to Colombia is not a simple process. There are visa requirements that can be difficult to fulfill, and staying for an extended period of time takes some research, resourcefulness, and commitment. Luckily, research, resourcefulness, and commitment are some of my strong suits, but I had to ask myself if that is what I really wanted to do with these few free years of my life.

I was supposed to make a third trip to Colombia during Winter Break of 2012/2013 to check out Medellin and determine which region to move to. I ended up cancelling that trip. I figured I would return to Colombia in August no matter what, and I should check out Central America first. My rationale was that after heading to South America again would I ever really want to go to Central America? I don’t think so.

Central America Journey

My Central America trip was not something that was planned. In fact, I woke up one Sunday morning and had an urge to travel. I researched countries all day, and after Monday I found out my back-ups at work were available so I bought my plane ticket that Monday evening.

I had 2 weeks between when I bought the ticket and when I would leave. I found out later that week that my final MBA project was not fulfilling the requirements and I needed to restart. Needless to say, things got very busy, very quickly. I’m quite the resourceful person, but even I couldn’t find any time to plan much for the trip.

Heading into the Central America journey, my plan for later that year (after I finished school) was to travel all of South America doing the normal backpacking thing. I had been well-traveled, but I had never tried the traditional backpacking thing. I decided giving it a shot for 2-3 weeks in Central America before I committed to a whole year in South America was a good idea.

The Central America destinations were split between 3 countries: Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Panama.

I won’t be going too far into the details of that trip, but the main point of it was to see if the backpacking thing was for me. I had a great time in Nicaragua with a couple friends I had met through Livemocha. Sofia had planned out some daytrips, and we had an amazing time during that first week. Based out of Managua, we took trips to various cities around Nicaragua such as Leon, Granada, Masaya, and the island of Ometepe. I thoroughly enjoyed that stage of the trip and Nicaragua was unforgettable.

The other parts of the trip through Costa Rica and Panama were the real backpacking portions of the trip. I was on my own doing the typical backpacking thing. I was staying in hostels, couchsurfing, and not knowing exactly where I would end up the next day.

To be honest, I didn’t enjoy this part of the trip too much, especially Costa Rica. I did meet some people along the way who I did enjoy, and there were plenty of good times. However, in general, I found that I have a better time living with locals and experiencing real culture instead of being around fellow travelers and trying to figure out what are the best things (aka, the touristy things) to do.

I prefer the simple things. I’m not into touristy towns, events, or activities. I enjoy walking through markets and streets, taking the bus while exploring, and learning about how people really live. I simply enjoy speaking Spanish. Costa Rica was super touristy, expensive, and seemingly everyone spoke English. Things were not going well in Costa Rica, although I must say it’s a close race between Switzerland and Costa Rica for the most beautiful countries I have been to.

It was beautiful, but it was not my style.

I found myself longing to be in Colombia during the Costa Rica and Panama parts of the trip. I had even seriously looked at flights from Costa Rica to Colombia, twice. My return flight departed from Panama City and I was thinking maybe I could fly to Colombia and then work my way back into Panama. It turned out those last minute plane tickets were too expensive, and I would need to tough it out.

The “aha moment” was when there was a not too impressive Colombian restaurant on the same block as my hostel in San Jose, Costa Rica. It’s a little embarrassing to say, but I got goosebumps when I saw the Colombian flag, and my eyes watered up a bit with excitement. Needless to say, I ate dinner there, and I ordered my favorite food in the whole world, a Bandeja Paisa. At that point I knew. I knew there was something special about Colombia.

Changing My Plans

After returning from Central America, my decision was not difficult to make. I found out the backpacking life wasn’t exactly my favorite thing in the world, but I also knew I still wanted to check out the other South American countries.

I decided to change my plans. Instead of travelling for a whole year, I would stay in Colombia for about 5-6 months and then make my way through South America for the rest of the year before ending in Brazil for the World Cup in June of 2014.

With this updated plan, it would give me more time to spend in my beloved Colombia, while also allowing ample time to casually make my way through the other countries on the road to Brazil. Maybe I’ll spend a month here, a month there? Maybe I’ll just spend a few days or weeks in the same areas? Maybe I’ll skip on some countries like Paraguay, Bolivia or Uruguay if time runs short? Who knows? I sure don’t. All I know is that I need a few months devoted solely to stay in Colombia.
fields.headline: To settle on Colombia, or to continue country hopping?
fields.title: Colombia or Latin America

fields.body:
As you may have read in The South American Dream, in the first year I’m going to be spending as much time in Colombia as I am in all the other 8 South American countries combined. Many people ask me, why Colombia?

Getting to know Colombia

It all started back in May of 2011. I was learning Spanish online through Livemocha and was helping native Spanish speakers with English while they were helping me with Spanish. On Livemocha, I quickly found out that 30-40% of the Spanish speakers learning English were from Colombia, and became curious. Why are there so many Colombians compared to the other countries?

After talking with about 3 people, I quickly found out how incredibly friendly Colombians were. Not only were they friendly, but they were just as interested in America as I was towards Colombia. I had grown up travelling in Europe and had been accustomed to other countries not having the best opinions about Americans, so this caught me by surprise.

I wondered if it was normal for Colombians to be like this, or was it just a subset of Colombians who were learning English that were super friendly and easy to talk with? The more people I talked to, the more confident I was in the good nature of Colombians as a whole. They have so much pride and love for their country, I haven’t seen anything like it. They are unimaginably happy with life, and it quickly rubbed off on me.

You might say,”but look at me, I’m happy with life.” That might be the case, but I guarantee it is different from how Colombians are. It is something unique. It is something I can’t explain. It is something I have talked with many people who have been to Colombia, and they can’t explain it either. The only way to understand is to go to the country and experience it first hand.

As the summer of 2011 progressed, I began to learn about various Colombian things. I was reading Colombian news from about 4 or 5 different sources. I was reading any Colombian blog I could find. I was listening to Colombian music, making Colombian food, watching Colombian T.V., drinking Colombian coffee, and admiring Colombian soccer. If it was Colombian, I was interested.

And then I decided to even try a long-distance relationship with a Colombian girl. It was great for about 6 months, but in the end it was just too difficult to sustain living like that and we were both not in positions to move.

The First Date with Colombia

Days turned into weeks and weeks turned into months. Finally it was December of 2011 and it was time to head to this land that had captivated all my interest for almost 6 months. The excitement and anxiety was through the roof, and it even rivals the excitement I feel today about finally being able to drop everything and move down there.

Despite some scares caused by a 2-hour plane delay which caused me to miss my connecting flight in Houston, I made it to Bogotá, Colombia. I was finally in this dream location I had been reading so much about. My girlfriend at the time, her sister, and her mom picked me up from the airport.

I still remember looking out the glass of the airport doors and seeing them with big smiles on their faces as I came through the door. I still remember the drizzling rain and the glow of lights off the pavement. I remember seeing people walking around in the lively city. I remember being happy and relieved to finally be in this wonderful land I had grown to love. There were so many unexplainable emotions, and that was the happiest I had ever felt. I knew from that day that Colombia would forever have an important impact on my life.

My first trip I spent about a week in Bogotá and some of the surrounding cities. We then travelled to the coast and spent a week in places like Parque Tayrona and the historic city of Cartagena. I also spent a couple days during New Year’s in a small town outside of Girardot at Camila’s sister’s house. They had a very different house than we’re accustomed to here, and I loved it. Oh, and they they also had an amazing pool to help cool off.

New Year’s in Girardot with Camila’s family solidified my feelings towards Colombia, and the Colombian culture. Experiencing New Year’s with a real Colombian family and real Colombian culture was an irreplaceable experience. For the second time on the trip, I had felt the happiest I had ever felt. That New Year’s Eve remains my favorite day of my life, and it will be tough to beat.

Taking the Next Step

As amazing as my first trip to Colombia was, it had to come to an end at some point. After two and a half weeks, I boarded the plane returning to the U.S. The next few months were difficult and extremely slow months because of the long-distance relationship as well as my desire to return to Colombia. Every day was a struggle, and I longed so desperately to be back in Colombia.

At that point, I had many ideas going through my head. Should I drop everything and move to Colombia? My custom-built house was less than a year old, I only had 1 year left until I finished my MBA, and I was enjoying my work. But my love for Colombia was enough to seriously consider leaving. In the end I decided to stick it out and wait to finish school. However, I lasted less than 3 months in the U.S. before returning to Colombia during my Spring Break.

Unfortunately, the second trip didn’t turn out as good as the first trip, but it was not Colombia’s fault. Our relationship ran into some issues and the situation with Camila got a bit dicey. It ended up being a more normal trip to Colombia and living a normal life as opposed to the first trip which was full of adventure.

However, the trip was still unforgettable, and my love for Colombia only continued to grow. You know something is right when the simple things are the exciting things. Taking a taxi, buying groceries, watching T.V., walking along the street, taking the bus, eating, people watching, and talking. It didn't matter what I was doing, I was always having a great time. I became more familiar with Bogotá and became comfortable moving around the city by myself without anyone's aid. I started to learn the streets, neighborhoods, stores, and directions. I started to feel like I belonged there. I started to truly feel Colombian, and it felt fantastic.

Broader Horizons

Yet again, I had to leave behind Colombia, but I knew I would be back. The only question was when. I figured I would come back during winter break and check out other parts of Colombia. I knew I wanted to move to Colombia, but I didn't exactly know where. My plans at the time were to return in December of 2012 and check out a city called Medellin and some areas around it and see if I wanted to move to Medellin or to Bogota.

However, over the course of a few months I decided to not return to Colombia at that time. It was not because the excitement of Colombia had dwindled, it was because I wanted to broaden my horizons. I decided to check out other Spanish speaking countries before I settled on Colombia.

Soon we’ll find out where I went (Here’s a hint) and what I found out. Was it just Colombia that’s special to me, or are there other countries that could give me the same feeling?

fields.title: Why Colombia?

fields.body:
Wow, I don’t even know where to start. I started learning Spanish in August of 2008 in a Spanish 101 college class during my last year of my undergraduate degree. The class was hands-down my favorite class I had ever taken, and I absolutely loved learning Spanish.

Growing up in my town in eastern Washington, I had been exposed to some Spanish here and there, but I had never formally learned it. Needless to say, I did well in the class, which felt more like a hobby than a class. It was an automatic A, but I still went over and beyond (which is unprecedented of me in school) because the language enthralled me.

I took the Spanish 102 class in my final semester of undergrad, and loved it the same. As much as I enjoyed my Spanish classes, I did not continue learning Spanish at that point, and I moved onto other hobbies.

Fast forward 2 years. My friend and former co-worker Michael Rainey told me about a website called Livemocha.com which has free, quality online interactive lessons in many languages. I decided to give it a shot, and after the first day, I instantly was hooked. For those who know me well, they know that when I really like something, I make it my life. It’s unhealthy to be honest. I became addicted to Spanish and it became my #1 priority for the next 8 months of my life.

Using all my free time, I tore through all the Spanish lessons within a month, and began talking to anyone I could find on Livemocha through their chat feature. They pair learners up so that I would talk to native Spanish speakers who were learning English and vice-versa.

It’s hard to express the change Livemocha caused in my life, and it’s even more difficult to understand. I began learning about different cultures, different countries, and different ways of life. I learned about various Latin American countries and formed an understanding of their people and their way of life.

Every day I longed to talk to my Livemocha friends, and some days I would Skype for hours. Those days were the best. I would chat, video chat, talk on the phone, watch TV and movies, listen to music - all in Spanish. Believe it or not, even my dog is now bi-lingual. There has always been something about te language that has made me happy. I’m not sure why.

My mood instantly changes when I talk Spanish and I become a completely different person. I become confident instead of timid. I become curious instead of reserved. I often ask myself “why can’t I be like this when I talk English?”, and after more than 2 years, I still don’t have the answer.

Prior to learning Spanish, I had gone through the 2 toughest years of my life. The language saved me - it made me happy when nothing else seemed to do the trick. My best explanation is that Spanish allows me to be who I really am. However, the question “why?” still exists. And to that question I have no answer but will be searching for the answer during my travels. Maybe some of you have ideas as to why this is, and I’d love to hear about it in the comments below.
fields.headline: how can language be this powerful?
fields.title: The Power of Spanish

fields.body:
Heading south....for a while

Formulating the South American Dream

We’re all familiar with the American Dream - move to the United States, find a job, move up the ladder, and live a successful life full of opportunity. After a year of learning spanish online and sharing my travel ambitions about South America, my peers dubbed me as having “The South American Dream”. I wanted to leave my stable, successful life in the United States to embark on a journey through Latin America to discover new cultures, language, and ways of life.

Here I am, roughly 2 years after formulating that dream, and I’m making it reality. Finally. There has been so much thought, research, and anxiety in the past couple years, and I’m so ready to embark on this journey. I’m ready to change the way I live, and truly gain my freedom. Being trapped in a world focused on my career and becoming successful, now is the time to change, and search for true happiness.

Route

Currently I am in the United States, and I will be leaving at the end of August. In June of 2014 I will be in Brazil for the World Cup. But... what about the 9 months in between? I’ve gone back and forth (and back again!) between a few options.

The first option was to backpack through South America, starting in Colombia and ending in Brazil. This plan was actually the front-runner as of 6 months ago. I decided to take a quick jaunt through Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Panama in March to test out backpacking because even though I’ve travelled quite a bit, I had never tried the backpacking thing. Through a mix of couchsurfing, hostels, and staying with a friend in Managua, I found out that the backpacking thing was not for me. I enjoyed most my time in Nicaragua because I was grounded with a couple Nicaraguan friends and we took day trips out to various places. After I left Managua, I started the actual backpacking thing. It’s not necessarily just “backpacking” that I don’t like, it’s having to rely on hostels and moving around constantly.

The next option was to find a job in my beloved Colombia and live there. I have to admit, this option has been super appealing to me, from the minute I took my first step in Colombia. I knew Colombia would always have a special place in my heart, but that topic I will have a full post dedicated to later! Anyway, the only downside to moving to Colombia was that I was scared. No, not of being kidnapped. No, not of being robbed. No... not of the drugs. All of those things are not prevalent in Colombia, and it is so much more than that, which you will find out through this blog. I was scared of staying! If I settle down in Colombia, I might not get another chance to travel like I have now. I didn’t want that to happen...

So the third option, which I developed on my backpacking trip through Central America, is to meet in the middle. My current plan is to live in Colombia for about 5 months and then over the next 4-5 months slowly make my way through South America towards Brazil. I’ll traverse through Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay and then finally Brazil. The details of this... well, they are non-existent! I have some plans to maybe backpack through Peru in February/March, but other than that, I’m just going to wing it. Total freedom, all day, everyday.

Questions, questions, questions!

So many questions from my friends and co-workers, which is to be expected. Many of the questions I have been asked repeatedly, and I’m starting to get tired of giving the same answers, however there are only a couple weeks left so I think I will survive.

What are you going to do with all your stuff?

Sell it. Get rid of it. Give it to family/friends. This was something I was looking forward to. I am not quite there yet, but I’m getting close. Liberating myself from my material possessions has been a process, but it is almost complete!

Are you going alone?

Yes! It would be so hard to embark on a journey like this with someone else, although Julia and Diego seem to find a way! The fact is that traveling alone and traveling with someone are completely different. People tend to have high level goals and desires when they travel. For me, right now, I travel to experience other cultures and improve my spanish. If I were to travel with someone, I would greatly hinder both of those goals. We wouldn’t be able to stay in places as easily, and flexibility would be diminished. We would need to decide what to do, where to go, what to eat, and all other decisions.

By going solo, I gain complete freedom and I can do whatever I want at all times. I have some friends in Colombia and Peru that I will meet with along the way, but I will also be making friends during my journey as well. On top of that, I will be with locals more learning about their culture and speaking spanish all the time. To me, it’s a no-brainer. I’m not built to long-term travel with other people, it goes against my goals of travel. Now, if I were going to a beach in the Caribbean for a week, that is different. My goal there would be to share the experience with someone, and in that case I would not mind traveling with someone.

But Colombia is so dangerous, aren’t you scared?

This is a question that really hits home with me, because I have such a soft spot in my heart for the wonderful country of Colombia. It’s been interesting hearing the different opinions of people now that they know my plans. They have conflicting opinions on if I’m making a smart decision or a dumb one. However, almost everyone has the same concerns about Colombia.

Well, no, I’m not scared. This will be the third time that I’ve gone to Colombia, and there is a reason why it is my favorite country out of the 26 that I have been lucky enough to visit so far in my life. The people are amazing. The country is beautiful. The culture is captivating. It pains me to hear these outdated opinions about Colombia, and for that one of my Goals is to spread the good word about Colombia. Anyway, I better write my Colombia blog post soon before it comes out in my other posts :)

What do you think of my South American dream and the route I’m choosing to take? Please feel free to comment below.

fields.title: The South American Dream

fields.body:
Here we are finally! I’ve been thinking about this blog for a couple years now and am so excited to begin this journey. If you have not read the About Me I would suggest reading that to gain a background on who I am. There are many things that I would love to write about, but after much thought, this blog is going to be focused around travelling, high-level life topics, and everyday life in Colombia. Here are my 3 goals:


Share information about travel throughout South America

There are plenty places to read about this topic, but my blog will not just be about traveling. I will be writing many posts about how travel affects life and happiness in general. I want to help people understand the possibility of travelling and invoke thoughts and ideas.


Discuss high-level topics on life

The topics of happiness and meaning of life have always captivated my interest. Finding meaning in life is something many people struggle with and it changes over time. There is no correct answer and everyone finds happiness and meaning in their lives in their own personal ways. I will discuss how I find happiness and maybe that will shed glimpses of light on fellow readers and followers.


Spread the great word about Colombia

In 2011 I fell in love with Colombia. The people are the warmest people I have ever met, it is truly incredible. The culture, lifestyle, and people of Colombia completely shocked me, and before I even set a foot in Colombia I knew it would have a huge impact on my life. I couldn't have been more right. The reasons for that I will discuss throughout this blog and hopefully continue to educate people on why it’s important for people to know about the current Colombia and not go by the reputation of pre-2003 Colombia.


There is so much more that will be discussed, but those are the high-level topics that the majority of my posts will cover. Over the past couple years I've been thinking about so many things, and I sincerely hope you enjoy them!
